urn:contentItem:5XD9-K3G1-F00C-60R4-00000-00Margrethe Vestager eyes toughening 'burden of proof' for Big Tech2019-10-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:40ZLexisNexisMargrethe Vestager eyes toughening 'burden of proof' for Big Tech

Large internet companies could be held to higher standards of proof in competition cases as part of changes to EU rules being considered by Margrethe Vestager.

The EU antitrust chief said she was examining a proposal from independent experts suggesting that digital platforms suspected of anti-competitive behaviour be required, in certain cases, to demonstrate clear gains for their users to avoid punitive measures - instead of Brussels having to show the damaging effects on consumers.

'I think it's an important discussion in figuring out what kind of regulation would be useful,' Ms Vestager told the Financial Times.

Stressing she had yet to reach a decision on whether to tighten the standard of proof, the Danish politician said that companies such as Google should bear extra responsibilities because they are so dominant that they have become 'de facto regulators' in their markets.

'When you own a market and you're the de facto market regulator, what are then the obligations that you get? And how do you show that you actually meet your obligations?,' the commissioner said.

Ms Vestager's tough line on Big Tech has won her both admirers and political enemies on both sides of the Atlantic during her first term in Brussels. The commissioner levied more than pound 8bn in antitrust fines on Google and demanded that Apple cough up pound 13bn in an illegal state aid case. As she prepares for a wider role under incoming commission president Ursula von der Leyen, Ms Vestager is envisaging an overhaul of EU regulation alongside further competition enforcement actions.

The change in the burden of proof would be limited in its scope, according to a person with direct knowledge of the talks. It would apply to companies preventing users from accessing multiple apps and companies blocking access to their data for third-party applications looking to offer supplementary services - such as apps that read emails.

'Say for instance, Uber started offering higher rates for those drivers who used its platform more often,' said this person. 'This would put competitors at a disadvantage because drivers would start favouring Uber to carry out their trips over competing apps. Under the proposed change it would be Uber who would need to show its behaviour is causing no harm to competition rather than the commission having to prove it.'

An EU official stressed that changing the burden of proof was one of several suggestions under review and there was no certainty it would be adopted.

But Ms Vestager, who will oversee EU digital policy in addition to her competition responsibilities, said: 'It's quite important to discuss fast and listen quick because there is a limit as to how much time we have available, because the legislative process in itself is quite long.'

Ms Vestager's stance on Silicon Valley has irked Donald Trump, US president, who accused her of hating America. Earlier this month she ordered US chipmaker Broadcom to stop alleged anti-competitive behaviour while a probe was ongoing, the first time the commission had applied so-called interim measures in nearly two decades.

'I'm particularly happy about the interim measures tool now being out of the toolbox,' Ms Vestager said. 'If we find cases where interim measures is the right tool to use, we will use it again.'

Among various ongoing inquiries, the commission was looking into Marketplace, Facebook's ecommerce app, and submitted a list of preliminary questions to the US company. 'We are still in the process of looking at the different answers, because obviously if we don't have a case, we don't have a case,' Ms Vestager said.

The commission has also set eyes on Apple Pay and it is exploring allegations that Wallet, the payment app on the iPhone, refuses to carry other payment apps.

Ms Vestager said the commission has also received calls from Google rivals to implement interim measures against the Silicon Valley company on Google Local and Google Travel, even though a probe is not imminent.

'I'd say sometimes, people ask for it, but sometimes, look at the Broadcom case, obviously, that was high priority, and yet, it takes a year before you get there,' she said. 'And here, we have quite a clear case about immediate risk on the market if interim measures are not imposed.'

Ms Vestager defended her wider commissioner's role and dismissed any potential conflicts of interest by saying there will enough scrutiny from EU courts and parliament on her actions.

'If you complain to us about not doing what we should, we shall have to reject that in public,' she said. 'We'll have to answer for ourselves.'

urn:contentItem:5X17-1731-F021-64NB-00000-00Margrethe Vestager gets second term in EU competition job;Dane has won renown for taking on tech firms, upsetting Donald Trump in the process2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:40ZLexisNexisWORLD NEWSVersion:1Margrethe Vestager gets second term in EU competition jobDane has won renown for taking on tech firms, upsetting Donald Trump in the processJennifer Rankin in Brussels

Margrethe Vestager, the high-flying Danish politician who has taken on Apple, Amazon and Google, will stay in charge of Europe's competition rules and take charge of EU digital policy.

Appointed to an unprecedented second term as the EU's competition commissioner, Vestager will also oversee EU digital policy and will have the job title of "executive vice-president, Europe fit for the digital age".

Vestager, who said she was "happy for and humbled by the task ahead", has been one of the most high-profile members of the current EU executive. Her competition job - in charge of vetting mergers and breaking up cartels - has always been a powerful position in the EU commission, and the Danish politician has won renown beyond Brussels by forcing Apple to pay (EURO)14bn in unpaid taxes and   fining Facebook for misleading regulators.

The appointment was announced by the incoming European commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, as she unveiled her lineup of EU commissioners.

Von der Leyen said Europe had to catch up in some aspects of digital technology. "We need to make the most of artificial intelligence and big data, we have to improve on cybersecurity and we have to work hard for our technological sovereignty."

Vestager won international recognition - and angered Donald Trump - when EU investigations found abuse of market power or   underpayment of corporate taxes at big tech companies. "Your tax lady, she really hates the US," Trump said in 2018 - an accusation   dismissed by Vestager.

In an interview with the Guardian last year, Vestager described how she feared technology could "deactivate democracy" as people retreated into their private news and information bubbles.

The new commission is due to take office on 1 November and must be confirmed by the European parliament.

In another surprise announcement, Italy's former prime minister Paolo Gentiloni was nominated as EU economy commissioner. His appointment, if confirmed, means he will have to enforce the EU's strict fiscal rules against his home country, one of the EU's most indebted states.

Gentiloni will report to Latvia's Valdis Dombrovskis, the current commissioner in charge of the euro, who has been made executive vice-president for "an economy that works for people".

France's Sylvie Goulard will take charge of the EU's internal market policy, while the Dutch commissioner Frans Timmermans will be in charge of climate change policy and enacting Von der Leyen's plans for a green new deal.

Ireland's Phil Hogan has been put in charge of EU trade policy, meaning he will negotiate ongoing trade deals with Australia and New Zealand as well as any future deal with post-Brexit Britain. He told the Irish Times it would take "a number of years" to craft a trade deal with the UK.

European commissioners swear an oath to act in the EU's general interest rather than that of any government. The British government, which traditionally sought big economic jobs on trade, competition or financial services, did not nominate a commissioner, in line with its goal of quitting the EU on 31 October.

urn:contentItem:5YG6-BWC1-JBKP-Y1BP-00000-00Margrethe Vestager: How Can We Ensure Fair Competition Online?2020-03-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:40ZLexisNexisTed Radio HourManoush ZomorodiMargrethe VestagerDonald TrumpMargrethe Vestager: How Can We Ensure Fair Competition Online?

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: OK. At this point, you might be feeling a little overwhelmed. Technology is growing fast. Misinformation is spreading quicker, and our digital economy is controlled by tech giants. If you want to shop, you go to Amazon. Social media - head to Facebook or Instagram, which Facebook owns. Searching the Web - you Google it. What's missing in all of this? A choice in the services we use, something one woman is working very hard to change.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: My name is Margrethe Vestager. I am the European commissioner for competition.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: And Margrethe says it's tough to ensure the Internet is safe and fair if the playing field is skewed.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: I work with competition law enforcement, making sure that companies don't do cartels.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: By cartels, she means businesses coming together to form monopolies.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: You cannot buy yourself a nice cartel. You cannot come together as businesses in secrecy squeezing out your competitors.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: You probably don't know many EU commissioners, but you might know Margrethe as the woman who's been fining tech companies for not following European law.

(SOUNDBITE OF MONTAGE)

UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER #1: Breaking news this morning. It is official...

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Today, the commission has decided to fine Google.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: In 2018, Margrethe slapped Google with a record fine of $5 billion.

(SOUNDBITE OF MONTAGE)

UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER #2: ...Five billion dollars.

UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER #3: ...Five billion dollars over its Android operating system.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: ...For breaching EU antitrust rules.

UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER #4: It's the largest antitrust penalty ever leveled at a single company.

UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER #2: The tech giant has 90 days to make changes, or face penalty payments.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: ...Penalty payments.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: She's launched investigations into Google, Amazon, Apple, Facebook.

(SOUNDBITE OF MONTAGE)

UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER #4: Margrethe Vestager, the EU's competition commissioner and resident dragon slayer.

DONALD TRUMP: She hates the United States perhaps worse than any person I've ever met.

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #1: Wow.

DONALD TRUMP: What she does to our country - she's suing all our companies. You know...

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: The purpose is to ensure competition and innovation for the benefits of European consumers.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: And that, she says, is the key to building an Internet we can trust.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Part of building trust is that you know there is a consequence if someone betrays your trust and do something illegal, something that they shouldn't do. Because if it's without consequence to betray people's trust, well, then trust disappears. And I think that is what is eroding societies and democracies. We need trust to make our society work.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: In just a moment, Margrethe Vestager explains how she's working to build that trust. On the show today - writing new rules for our online lives. I'm Manoush Zomorodi, and you're listening to the TED Radio Hour from NPR.

It's the TED Radio Hour from NPR. I'm Manoush Zomorodi. And on the show today - ideas about building trust in the internet.

We just heard from EU competition commissioner Margrethe Vestager, who says the best way to build that trust is to make competition fair. And to do that, Margrethe is looking to the past to the very first time that Europe built a fair marketplace across its borders.

(SOUNDBITE OF TED TALK)

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Let's go back to 1957 - Europe was destroyed.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: Here's Margrethe on the TED stage.

(SOUNDBITE OF TED TALK)

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: A world war had emerged from Europe. The human suffering was unbelievable and unprecedented.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

UNIDENTIFIED NARRATOR: The sound of ruin is silence. The smell of ruin is sick with the scent of dead and dust.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: In order to avoid Europe being sort of the cradle (ph) of a third world war, we have to do something radical. We have to work together in a different way.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

UNIDENTIFIED NARRATOR: Will there be peace or war?

(SOUNDBITE OF TED TALK)

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Representatives from six European countries had come to Rome to sign the treaty that were to create the European Union. And one of the many building blocks was a common European market.

Part of the inspiration came from the U.S. because in the U.S., that was already sort of part of the societal contract for decades by the Sherman Act. So they took the inspiration from antitrust to say, well, you have to be innovative. You have to offer affordable prices, good service, high quality, come up with the latest.

So we put a frame around this market to control bad behavior, and within that framework, we say now go compete. Now let the market powers work so that the customers and consumers, they get the best of what a market can offer.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: So how unlikely was it that people would actually come together to agree on this standard set of rules?

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Well, I think back then, it was almost a miracle because we have a history of fighting our neighbors.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Coming together and agreeing, not only on values, but also how you put values into real life, that was a manmade miracle. And here, literally men because it was men who was writing these rules.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: (Laughter).

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: But the thing is that it worked. Europe has been at peace ever since.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: But the key difference now is that we have a global economy that's driven by big tech companies, right? They have the highest valuations of any corporations. They operate around the world and on the Internet, and governments haven't really placed boundaries on them. So where are we now when we look back at 1957 in terms of applying those ideas?

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Well, we still have some way to go, to say it mildly, but the fundamentals are the same. The reason why it was necessary to frame the market in this respect was human nature. And human nature doesn't change with digital technology because it's about greed and fear and power. Of course, we are profoundly challenged to fully grasp a fully digital economy because the dynamics are different from how it was in the old days, 10 years ago - also because we're in the midst sort of of breaking the fiction of the Web as a place of freedom.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: The Web is a very commercial place. It's a place where you also find some of the things that we have long, long time agreed on in the real world that we will not accept, like, you know, handing out bomb recipes, child abuse, incitement to terrorism. So there are temptations, there are conflicts, there are evil things that we'll have to deal with. And I think we are better off and much wiser if we look at the digital part of our society, of our market with the same eyes as we would look at the rest of the world because otherwise, I don't think that we can maintain democracy.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: So with that in mind, as commissioner, what sort of scenarios prompt you to do an investigation? Like, in my head, I'm thinking maybe small businesses who are selling their stuff on Amazon but struggling to compete with Amazon itself.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Exactly. And we do have an Amazon investigation in issues exactly as the one you just described. Because on the one hand side, it is great that small vendors can find a marketplace where they can be helped with shipping and payments and, you know, the things that makes it easy to do e-commerce. On the other hand side, it's not that good if the one who holds the marketplace also takes all the data that comes from your sale. And they have this information from all the vendors, then they themselves becomes an incredible competitor to you.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Because imagine sort of an old-school marketplace where you have people coming in with their different products. You would never accept if the municipality who owned the marketplace had a giant shop where they would sell things that were similar to the products that the vendors who had paid for their stalls in the marketplace that they would sell. And there's a lot of parallels in sort of the real world where we have discussed in depth how we would like things to be and agreed upon it and enforced it over decades. And I think only because we have had this illusion of the Internets and the digital world being special and free and innovative, we have kind of let go of some of the things that were fundamental to us.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: So, clearly, small businesses benefit from your work, but what about the big guys? Some of them are kind of trying to beat you to the punch. Mark Zuckerberg, the CEO of Facebook, for example, has said he wants to be regulated. Please, put framework around our company so we know when we're complying and not complying, he's basically said. Do you think that's just lip service?

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Of course, I'm not in Mark Zuckerberg's head, but I think he's right that regulation is needed. But if you want regulation, you would also start with yourself. You would consider your business to say, well, I know it takes time for a regulator to get the legislation right, so I will start with myself to make sure that my fundamental values and the values reflected in the society where I do my business, that they are also reflected in the way I do business.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: Do you think that people are starting to understand that what happens online in the digital space really does affect what happens in the real world, that the two aren't that separate?

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: I think so. I think slowly but surely.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: For me, the important thing is that we live in a world with consequences, that be a digital world or a physical world or when the two things they kind of melt together as they do now. Just as there's no such thing as a free lunch, I'd say there's no such thing as a paradise without a snake.

MANOUSH ZOMORODI: That's EU Commissioner Margrethe Vestager. You can find her full talk at ted.com.

urn:contentItem:5YRS-P4X1-JCJY-G30V-00000-00Margrethe Vestager: 'If tech firms do something illegal we will pursue them';The EU's leading monopoly enforcer says tech titans will not exploit the coronavirus pandemic on her watch2020-04-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:40ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYVersion:2Margrethe Vestager: 'If tech firms do something illegal we will pursue them'The EU's leading monopoly enforcer says tech titans will not exploit the coronavirus pandemic on her watchBy Laurence Dodds, US Technology Reporter

Who can stop Silicon Valley now? After years on the defensive against a worldwide "techlash" that threatened to break up their empires, tech giants have suddenly become essential services.

Governments need them to control misinformation and track disease; citizens rely on them simply to work and stay sane; their rivals are drowning, while their own cash reserves are gigantic. Surely, then, this is their hour of domination?

Not if Margrethe Vestager has anything to do with it. Asked whether she is concerned that American tech firms will exploit the coronavirus crisis to cement their power by snapping up rivals or conquering new markets, the European Union's top monopoly enforcer only retorts: "Well, not with me!"

Speaking to the Telegraph from the EU's hulking Berlaymont building in Brussels, now empty save for a tiny core of staff who are not working from home, the former Danish finance minister, who turned 52 this month, vows that her office will remain "vigilant".

"We have not changed our perspective when it comes to the obligations of a dominant company," she says. "If they do something that is illegal, we'll have to pursue those cases." Indeed, the EU is still pressing forward with new regulations - a necessity that she says the crisis only "enhances".

It is a strong signal from a woman who has already levied billions of dollars in fines against Big Tech. As the European Commission's competition minister since 2014, she has launched probes into Google, Apple and Amazon that drew the ire of Donald Trump (as well as a typical Trumpian sobriquet: "the tax lady").

In December, under the new Commission president Ursula von der Leyen, she was promoted to oversee of all digital affairs- widely taken as a sign that Brussels' war on Silicon Valley would only heat up.

Now there is a bigger battle. The fiscally unthinkable has become routine almost overnight, and state aid to private companies - a core target of Ms Vestager's office - is one of the only things keeping the European economy afloat.

The Commission has relaxed those rules, pledging to do   "whatever is necessary", but member states are now squabbling over relief measures along the same north-south divide that bedevilled the last crash.

That makes Ms Vestager's work rather hectic. When she speaks to the Telegraph she has just finished eating a quick dinner microwaved in her office, where she also keeps a small ceramic sculpture of an upthrust middle finger to remind her that she can't please everybody.

Despite being in the hotseat for the Great Recession, she says this is like nothing she's faced: "This doesn't compare to anything. It is unprecedented, historic in every respect." The risks, too, are "quite profound": hostile takeovers by powerful companies sensing opportunity in crisis, smaller companies desperate for a saviour, and hugely increased cybercrime and fraud.

One potential sign of the potential consolidation dangers is Facebook's recent deal with the Indian mobile giant Reliance Jio. Facebook will pay $5.7bn (£4.6bn), its largest ever single investment, for10pc of the biggest mobile operator in a country where it has long coveted expansion.

The crisis has also caused the US telecom firm Verizon to bite the bullet on a long-mooted acquisition of BlueJeans, a video-conferencing service and rival to the ascendant but vulnerable Zoom.

Ms Vestager, however, is keen to stress business as usual. She declines to be drawn on whether the pandemic actually increases the risk of Silicon Valley dominance. Surrounded by tremendous upheaval, she insists on continuities in the EU's approach. She grants that US tech firms are always on the hunt, but says that has been true for years.

One thing she is not cagey about is the threat of takeovers by foreign state-backed companies. With Europe's economy on life support, she warns that there is more danger than ever of such companies using their generous access to government credit to "import unfair competition" into the EU and acquire rivals while they are in a vulnerable state.

"Since we have been hit by the virus in different stages, it's also probable that we could recover in different stages," she says. "So one could imagine that European businesses would be in a weakened position when other regions have recovered.

"Here, I think it's important to send the signal that we will be vigilant... that we would actually stand by [strategic] companies."

In a past interview with the Belgian magazine Knack, Ms Vestager singled out   China in particular, saying that its companies are now in a "later phase of the crisis". Indeed, Britain recently blocked a plan by a Beijing-backed venture capitalists to   tighten control over Imagination Technologies, a UK chip designer.

But she also cites Germans' fury over a report that Donald Trump had offered $1bn to a home-grown pharma company for exclusive rights to its vaccine. Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund has likewise been shopping for bargains.

To prevent that, she has given EU member states her blessing to buy defensive stakes of their own, and is working on more aggressive methods of screening foreign investments. Those signals, she said last week, are "intended for both camps".

Even so, how strict can she really afford to be, given the scale of the crisis? The British Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) spent almost a year scrutinising Amazon's investment in Deliveroo, but on April 17 itsuddenly gave it a provisional green light.

The reason was simple: the potential damage to consumers of Amazon taking a stake were now totally eclipsed by the risk of Deliveroo going bust.

Ms Vestager does accept that regulators will often end up more lenient in effect. Mergers that might otherwise have been denied could be approved if the alternative is one company collapsing; collaborations between companies that might normally be banned by anti-cartel laws are already being authorised in the name of keeping up supplies.

EU rules allow exceptions for "dramatic, extraordinary events", she says, and this is one.

"But," she adds, "the world is still inhabited by humans. Just as we see businesses go to extraordinary lengths to produce ventilators and protective gear, you will also see that there are some crisis privateers... it's important to be extremely helpful where it makes sense, and at the same time to stay vigilant so that people do not fall victim."

For what it's worth, she says she trusts tech giants not to be privateers - if only because everyone is watching them.

Not that tech's new eminence has convinced her that big is beautiful. While she demurs at the idea that internet services should be treated like public utilities, she does argue that greater dominance confers greater duty.

She cites new EU laws, taking effect this summer, that will force digital marketplaces such as Amazon and Google to explain their search rankings, disclose how they are boosting their own products and give their sellers the right to appeal against decisions.

"If you win the market, you become a de factor regulator of that market, setting the rules of the game," she says. "You're more than welcome to be successful, but you're not supposed to misuse your powers to promote yourself."

Her strongest response is to the suggestion that competition laws should take a back seat in a crisis of this scale. "Actually I think that competition law enforcement is an essential necessity. It is anything but a luxury," she says.

When the US suspended some antitrust action after 2008, it actually postponed the recession. "You need competition to ensure that companies that create jobs can survive, that companies that are innovative survive."

Her vision is that much of this competition will come from Europe itself. She lists areas where European firms could excel, and sees the very risk of American predation as proof of their potential.

"There is more to digitisation than what the giants are providing right now," she says, seeing in the recovery a chance to "accelerate" EU prowess.

That truly would be a historic conclusion to the great isolation: triumph not for Californian incumbents but for the long-prophesied, ever-elusive European Google.

urn:contentItem:5TCD-B3W1-DY0W-44HT-00000-00Margrethe Vestager is interviewed on BB Surveillance2018-09-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:40ZLexisNexisMargrethe Vestager is interviewed on BB SurveillanceLanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JOHN MICKLETHWAIT, BLOOMBERG, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF: Thank you very much. We just have the video which I think sets the scene both for this session and the one after. Big picture view of technology but I suspect our job is to get down the nitty-gritty.

We have you in front of us possibly the most frightening women to big pet, the E.U. Commissioner. You find Google, you chase and live Apple tax bill, now you've announced an early stage probe into Amazon.

And I wondered what the aim about was? I know you came to stress that you want to encourage investment but what exactly you're looking as on Apple -- on Amazon?

MARGRETHE VESTAGER, EU COMPETITON COMMISSIONER: Well Amazon is a --it's a two sided of market. They have dual functions. They both host the little guy, so can he can enter into e-commerce. They provide a number of services which allows also smaller businesses to be active e-commerce and to grab the opportunities and that's great.

There are also big guy themselves, bookstore, you know, everything, groceries, movies, the works. And they of course get all the data from the little guy and we want to understand how these data is being used. Because this is all about competition. Because when we say innovation, well, competition is the most important driver for innovation for you to stay ahead of you competitor.

MICKLETHWAIT: Would you think the future is a bit like telecom companies or maybe what happened was Microsoft many years ago where you have a platform company which is then force to let other people trade and have access to that platform.

VESTAGER: Well, I think that's very difficult to say because as it was just set in the video this is a -- this is a revolution, things changed. And we haven't even what is coming with quantum computing, blockchains, sort of really pulling of.

So, we probably have a platform economy that's much more diverse than what we have seen, which is why of course it's important for us to understand, well, what is the new big? How companies that benefit from network effects from huge amount of data, from marginal cost approaching zero, how do they compete? And for us that, of course, is the important thing.

MICKLETHWAIT: Do you think in some ways competition lower is being left behind by big tech? You have these companies where you talked about network effects. It is very difficult to intervene until of that they have created this a space there in monopoly and some people would see them?

VESTAGER: I think -- I think our principles are fine because they are about human nature and rhythm change, unfortunately. With all our good sides and bad sides, I think we remain the same. But of course in the regulation we need to stay alert, because you can be big. In Europe, you can be successful. But you should misuse your power.

This is actually the story of the two Google fines. Very successful, very welcome in Europe but we find that they misused their power for competitive not be as innovative as they ought to, for consumers not to be able to enjoy the benefits of choice, innovation, affordable prices. And that of course is where we have to be very, very vigilant.

MICKLETHWAIT: And isn't it the Google thing of an example of what I just said, you know, it took you seven years in tech. Seven years is a lifetime.

VESTAGER: Yes, part of that is part of the game because there is an asymmetry in every kind of law enforcement. Because (INAUDIBLE) it takes five minutes to break into to your home. It will take the police and the court system quite some time to find the guilty person, to get him or her convicted in its way.

MICKLETHWAIT: That's with not seven years?

VESTAGER: No, but you still have responsibility to do process. Because we live in a union base under the rule of law and we will never ever compromise on your right to defend yourself. That being said, of course, we can use algorithms too. We can too use all the tools of the digital world in order for us to be more speedy.

MICKLETHWAIT: Do you thing tech homes of simply become too big in some cases?

VESTAGER: No I don't as such that you can make that conclusion but I think they can be much more transparent. My colleagues have made, I think very, very, good proposals to ensure transparency in the relationship between the smaller business and the platform and that I think is very much needed to transparency, the willingness actually to deal with people. And to be much more sort of clear that they respect your privacy, your ownership of your own data so that we are citizen feel that we can built trust with technology.

MICKLETHWAIT: And do you thing (INAUDIBLE) scenario where the EU could take a lead?

VESTAGER: Well, I think the rights that are now much more clear. If you own your data, that you have a right to be forgotten, that you have a right to know what is out there with you that you have for ability so you can move your data.

I think in not only having the rules but also implementing the rules. Of course, this is something that's important for us as Europeans. And we do hope that we can inspire around the world because I think that respect of a citizen is what builds trust.

MICKLETHWAIT: But you know what some people in this audience will think specially Americans, they will think, look, this is Europe doesn't have any big tech companies or circling enough from the scale the America does and that China is where we surely see.

And this is Europe just trying to pull back America. Do you think that what is your -- what is your analysis to that suspicion.

VESTAGER: What I think the reason why business in Europe is because they do very good business. And you see a number of the US companies they are dominant in the European markets and they are more than welcome to be that.

An when you see, look at our tax growths, because you're more than welcome as a European members states within or outside of union so set your own level of corporate taxation. But you're not supposed to handout specific favors that be to Apple or to Starbucks or to some of the European companies where we've seen that happen as well.

It's not about your flag. It's not about whether you're privately a publicly earned. It's about your competitors spirit. You're supposed to compete for you business in Europe.

MICKLETHWAIT: And when you look at these new cases you're taking on, do you look back to old cases like IBM many yeas ago or Microsoft, and trying to see there's sort of like inspiration for this? Are there lessons you can learn from past periods of antitrust?

VESTAGER: I think there's an important lesson of that speed as you just said. Because if things takes forever then it's not the antitrust enforcement that sort of make sure that what we do as authorities leave sufficient room for all the many, many, many businesses who compete by the book who do their best, scale them for years, trying to make it in the marketplace. They should know, of course, that justice is sufficiently fast for them to enjoy a competitive marketplace.

MICKLETHWAIT: Do you think there's something different about technology with government now? You look at other industries and government can leave them alone and these sort of industries there is a tendency as you said because of network affects towards having monopolies, towards having that form of effect. And so in some way, is government to rethink.

VESTAGER: I think in order to be able to do that we have to work with the fact everything did utilizes. Agriculture, health, administration, everything digitalizes. So, if you want to accommodate and make a good business environment for that, of course, you have to be able to understand it. And this is why the partnership with business in order how to get that right. That's important for us. That's important for government.

MICKLETHWAIT: Well, a very quick last question, (INAUDIBLE) because you mentioned in earlier and Theresa May did -- she talks about Britain now having the lowest corporation tax. Do you think that is a good way to negotiate with the Europe Union?

VESTAGER: Well it doesn't change much because also within the union in the very basic treaties are some member state, you have the right to set your level of corporate taxation, and that, you can do within the union or outside of the union.

What we don't want within the union is that member states puts money in one business pocket not allowing anyone else to have the same thing, because that's not fair competition. But on the level of corporate taxation, you can compete within and without the European Union.

MICKLETHWAIT: Thank you very much commissioner.

(BREAK)

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5TCD-B3W1-DY0W-44JC-00000-00Margrethe Vestager is interviewed on BB Surveillance2018-09-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:40ZLexisNexisMargrethe Vestager is interviewed on BB SurveillanceWalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JOHN MICKLETHWAIT, BLOOMBERG, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF: Thank you very much. We just have the video which I think sets the scene both for this session and the one after. Big picture view of technology but I suspect our job is to get down the nitty-gritty.

We have you in front of us possibly the most frightening women to big pet, the E.U. Commissioner. You find Google, you chase and live Apple tax bill, now you've announced an early stage probe into Amazon.

And I wondered what the aim about was? I know you came to stress that you want to encourage investment but what exactly you're looking as on Apple -- on Amazon?

MARGRETHE VESTAGER, EU COMPETITON COMMISSIONER: Well Amazon is a --it's a two sided of market. They have dual functions. They both host the little guy, so can he can enter into e-commerce. They provide a number of services which allows also smaller businesses to be active e-commerce and to grab the opportunities and that's great.

There are also big guy themselves, bookstore, you know, everything, groceries, movies, the works. And they of course get all the data from the little guy and we want to understand how these data is being used. Because this is all about competition. Because when we say innovation, well, competition is the most important driver for innovation for you to stay ahead of you competitor.

MICKLETHWAIT: Would you think the future is a bit like telecom companies or maybe what happened was Microsoft many years ago where you have a platform company which is then force to let other people trade and have access to that platform.

VESTAGER: Well, I think that's very difficult to say because as it was just set in the video this is a -- this is a revolution, things changed. And we haven't even what is coming with quantum computing, blockchains, sort of really pulling of.

So, we probably have a platform economy that's much more diverse than what we have seen, which is why of course it's important for us to understand, well, what is the new big? How companies that benefit from network effects from huge amount of data, from marginal cost approaching zero, how do they compete? And for us that, of course, is the important thing.

MICKLETHWAIT: Do you think in some ways competition lower is being left behind by big tech? You have these companies where you talked about network effects. It is very difficult to intervene until of that they have created this a space there in monopoly and some people would see them?

VESTAGER: I think -- I think our principles are fine because they are about human nature and rhythm change, unfortunately. With all our good sides and bad sides, I think we remain the same. But of course in the regulation we need to stay alert, because you can be big. In Europe, you can be successful. But you should misuse your power.

This is actually the story of the two Google fines. Very successful, very welcome in Europe but we find that they misused their power for competitive not be as innovative as they ought to, for consumers not to be able to enjoy the benefits of choice, innovation, affordable prices. And that of course is where we have to be very, very vigilant.

MICKLETHWAIT: And isn't it the Google thing of an example of what I just said, you know, it took you seven years in tech. Seven years is a lifetime.

VESTAGER: Yes, part of that is part of the game because there is an asymmetry in every kind of law enforcement. Because (INAUDIBLE) it takes five minutes to break into to your home. It will take the police and the court system quite some time to find the guilty person, to get him or her convicted in its way.

MICKLETHWAIT: That's with not seven years?

VESTAGER: No, but you still have responsibility to do process. Because we live in a union base under the rule of law and we will never ever compromise on your right to defend yourself. That being said, of course, we can use algorithms too. We can too use all the tools of the digital world in order for us to be more speedy.

MICKLETHWAIT: Do you thing tech homes of simply become too big in some cases?

VESTAGER: No I don't as such that you can make that conclusion but I think they can be much more transparent. My colleagues have made, I think very, very, good proposals to ensure transparency in the relationship between the smaller business and the platform and that I think is very much needed to transparency, the willingness actually to deal with people. And to be much more sort of clear that they respect your privacy, your ownership of your own data so that we are citizen feel that we can built trust with technology.

MICKLETHWAIT: And do you thing (INAUDIBLE) scenario where the EU could take a lead?

VESTAGER: Well, I think the rights that are now much more clear. If you own your data, that you have a right to be forgotten, that you have a right to know what is out there with you that you have for ability so you can move your data.

I think in not only having the rules but also implementing the rules. Of course, this is something that's important for us as Europeans. And we do hope that we can inspire around the world because I think that respect of a citizen is what builds trust.

MICKLETHWAIT: But you know what some people in this audience will think specially Americans, they will think, look, this is Europe doesn't have any big tech companies or circling enough from the scale the America does and that China is where we surely see.

And this is Europe just trying to pull back America. Do you think that what is your -- what is your analysis to that suspicion.

VESTAGER: What I think the reason why business in Europe is because they do very good business. And you see a number of the US companies they are dominant in the European markets and they are more than welcome to be that.

An when you see, look at our tax growths, because you're more than welcome as a European members states within or outside of union so set your own level of corporate taxation. But you're not supposed to handout specific favors that be to Apple or to Starbucks or to some of the European companies where we've seen that happen as well.

It's not about your flag. It's not about whether you're privately a publicly earned. It's about your competitors spirit. You're supposed to compete for you business in Europe.

MICKLETHWAIT: And when you look at these new cases you're taking on, do you look back to old cases like IBM many yeas ago or Microsoft, and trying to see there's sort of like inspiration for this? Are there lessons you can learn from past periods of antitrust?

VESTAGER: I think there's an important lesson of that speed as you just said. Because if things takes forever then it's not the antitrust enforcement that sort of make sure that what we do as authorities leave sufficient room for all the many, many, many businesses who compete by the book who do their best, scale them for years, trying to make it in the marketplace. They should know, of course, that justice is sufficiently fast for them to enjoy a competitive marketplace.

MICKLETHWAIT: Do you think there's something different about technology with government now? You look at other industries and government can leave them alone and these sort of industries there is a tendency as you said because of network affects towards having monopolies, towards having that form of effect. And so in some way, is government to rethink.

VESTAGER: I think in order to be able to do that we have to work with the fact everything did utilizes. Agriculture, health, administration, everything digitalizes. So, if you want to accommodate and make a good business environment for that, of course, you have to be able to understand it. And this is why the partnership with business in order how to get that right. That's important for us. That's important for government.

MICKLETHWAIT: Well, a very quick last question, (INAUDIBLE) because you mentioned in earlier and Theresa May did -- she talks about Britain now having the lowest corporation tax. Do you think that is a good way to negotiate with the Europe Union?

VESTAGER: Well it doesn't change much because also within the union in the very basic treaties are some member state, you have the right to set your level of corporate taxation, and that, you can do within the union or outside of the union.

What we don't want within the union is that member states puts money in one business pocket not allowing anyone else to have the same thing, because that's not fair competition. But on the level of corporate taxation, you can compete within and without the European Union.

MICKLETHWAIT: Thank you very much commissioner.

(BREAK)

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

MARGRETHE VESTAGER, EUROPEAN COMMISSIONER FOR COMPETITION, DENMARK, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

SEPTEMBER 18, 2017

SPEAKERS: MARGRETHE VESTAGER, EUROPEAN COMMISSIONER FOR COMPETITION, DENMARK

DAVID GURA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: I'm Emily Chang and this Bloomberg Technology. Coming up, Margrethe Vestager goes to Washington. It is her job to keep big tech in check. The European Commissioner for Competition joins us for a wide ranging interview.

SEPTEMBER 18, 2017

GURA: Let me start by asking about the meetings that you had today that you met with folks with FTC in the Department of Justice. Just share if you could, the substance of those conversation. What were you talking to those kind of reports events today?

VESTAGER: Well, we don't share the substance.

GURA: Yes.

VESTAGER: Because very often, we have the opportunity just to takes trunk (ph) of open cases. And since they're open, of course, this is not something that we can share with the wider audience.

GURA: Keeping that what we've read in the news about making fees of these departments, the fact that you have people in an intern basis feeling a lot of these rules at the FTC at the Department of Justice. Is that nearly a frustration or is that proven to be difficult as you work with counterparts across the Atlantic area? Is it somehow different not having permit political appointees in place to these organizations?

VESTAGER: Well maybe to some degree in the beginning I wonder, but now I got to know both Maureen Ohasen (ph) and Venderfrench Rutherwell (ph). I met a couple of times and there is such a strong culture, a very concrete cooperation between the case teams because they share this culture of serving the consumer in the market. And therefore, you know, it is very concrete. It's very directed. It's a very good corporation.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER, EUROPEAN COMMISSIONER FOR COMPETITION, DENMARK, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

SEPTEMBER 18, 2017

SPEAKERS: MARGRETHE VESTAGER, EUROPEAN COMMISSIONER FOR COMPETITION, DENMARK

DAVID GURA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: I'm Emily Chang and this Bloomberg Technology. Coming up, Margrethe Vestager goes to Washington. It is her job to keep big tech in check. The European Commissioner for Competition joins us for a wide ranging interview.

(BREAK)

CHANG: But first to our lead, European regulators are stepping up their pressure on U.S. Tech companies with European Commissioner for Competition, Margrethe Vestager at the helm. The E.U. has announced massive fines against Apple and Google.

This week, she's in the U.S. visiting her American counterpart as well as tough political leaders. So what is on the agenda? I want to get straight now to my colleague David Gura who is in Washington. David, take it away.

DAVID GURA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Emily, thank you very much. Commissioner Vestager, thank you very much for your time this afternoon, always very busy day for you.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER, EUROPEAN COMMISSIONER FOR COMPETITION, DENMARK: Great to be with you.

GURA: Let me start by asking about the meetings that you had today that you met with folks with FTC in the Department of Justice. Just share if you could, the substance of those conversation. What were you talking to those kind of reports events today?

VESTAGER: Well, we don't share the substance.

GURA: Yes.

VESTAGER: Because very often, we have the opportunity just to takes trunk (ph) of open cases. And since they're open, of course, this is not something that we can share with the wider audience.

GURA: Keeping that what we've read in the news about making fees of these departments, the fact that you have people in an intern basis feeling a lot of these rules at the FTC at the Department of Justice. Is that nearly a frustration or is that proven to be difficult as you work with counterparts across the Atlantic area? Is it somehow different not having permit political appointees in place to these organizations?

VESTAGER: Well maybe to some degree in the beginning I wonder, but now I got to know both Maureen Ohasen (ph) and Venderfrench Rutherwell (ph). I met a couple of times and there is such a strong culture, a very concrete cooperation between the case teams because they share this culture of serving the consumer in the market. And therefore, you know, it is very concrete. It's very directed. It's a very good corporation.

GURA: According to this (ph), give me some insight into that cooperation. You're doing your investigations, working on your own cases that's happening here in U.S. as well. What's the ideal relationship like between your office and the FTC say with the Department of Justice?

VESTAGER: Well, to some degree, actually we have a different legal basis. So it's not just all just the same. But with the necessary wavers and businesses, we can discuss an exchange to test hypothesis about would this be a competition concern? How do you see this?

So the case team, they called each other. Sometimes they come together. We have had a U.S., people coming over for somewhat we're hearings. We go here. It's something you can create happening. So it's quite into twins. Of course, very respectful of the differences but also they're concrete on making it right. I guess you have very high quality in the case works.

GURA: A question to you as an observer of this place, I think you and I last spoke, you were here after the election. So you've spent some time in D.C.. Does the train look different from you? Does the rhetoric about anti-trust for instance or computational regulations sound different coming to Washington now seven, eighth months into this president's throne?

VESTAGER: Well, I -- if you could see, there is a renewed interests, more debates. I saw it over the -- in the election campaign. There is a sort of -- I think there is more debate that how to make sure that consumers is a well-served. How to make sure that you have right in competition, because competition is a driver not only for low prices and choice but also for innovation to be able to in the future to produce affordable prices and choice and a lots of going on here. And I find out they're very inspiring.

GURA: A couple of days ago since senators on Capitol Hill proposed an emergency (ph) from enforcement, senator Amy Klobuchar among them. And the point that she was making as I understand is the rules, the policies were outdated. We need to refresh them. Taking as a broad perspective on that, when you look at policy, enforcement policy broadly speaking, that need to be updated, do you think? Do you feel that policy haven't get step with where things when it comes to technology say?

VESTAGER: Well, for obvious reason, I've been looking at the European Situation. And of course, we've been off guard sort of the same question because markets are developing very fast. Things are changing. Tech introduce life session, it's forming out society. But I find that our basic rules, they're fine because some of the narratives, were there the same.

It's great. It's fear combine with power that can be a very, very strong combination. And we can do with us. Our challenge is of course to keep our chores sharp. And also to develop new tools because we have to be a skilled when it comes to going through massive amounts of data as anyone else. And that of course is the challenge but we accept it to develop with the phase of the market participants.

GURA: Which one do that cooperation help problematic if you guys are not on the same page? I think when you have been or with Albert (ph), and that was huge for instance, when you look at call coming the next day, and you're in different counts, it seems like what kind of problems does that post if any when you and U.S. are doing the same page?

VESTAGER: Well, exactly. In this example that certainly mentioned should be seen because we're not done yet. But it happens quite rarely. When it happens, I think very often, they are very concrete reasons that the market situation is not the same. The market participants play different roles. So very often I find that you have adaptive reasons when we divide in how we look at, let's say, other case.

GURA: How do you use that the advocacy of what you're doing? I think we first spoke after you left into that's fund on Apple, the 13 billion Euros. Have you started to see changes as a result of that? Do you see companies where reconsidering -- publicly reconsidering, privately talking about the way that they apply their taxes. We're going to pay their taxes because they have an affect in the way companies, that work with policy perspective?

VESTAGER: Well, yes I think that change is coming. It is slow because it take sometime and I think it will be far so when our courts have that with the cases. But you also see members states starting themselves to change the legislation. In Luxembourg and try first on the financing companies, in Ireland on the legislation allowing for what we called a double Irish which is being out phase.

And then of course, the legislative phase in Europe Union as a such has also a changed. There is much more bigger. And member say, it's a much more ready to say, well, we want the level flying field. And we want our tax priorities to work together in order to get it right because we see so many businesses. They pay their taxes exactly as one would expect. That do not just be for the many, it should be for everyone.

GURA: You speak today with North of Kremlin looking to buy orbital ATK. You're seeing a lot of consolidation of very big companies reducing the size of the plain field. There are number of sectors that there are on space, your defense. Is that inherently a problematic thing? Does it raise concerns to see big companies merging, acquiring and the field of players becoming smaller?

VESTAGER: Well, it always depends because sometimes we see that it may be possible for a merger to enable -- there were process to consumers that efficiency is going to be passed on to consumers. So we never have sort of an opinion beforehand. We go into the analysis with an open mind to make sure that also post merger, that consumers will be real tough (ph).

GURA: Just to assume inside if you're willing to -- how do you decide which case is to take up with the processes like it leads to investigation of the opening of the case.

VESTAGER: Well, merges, they just knocking our door, so.

GURA: Yes. And that's been the many times to have fun.

VESTAGER: Yes. So those, we just do head on. In the anti-trust cases, for instance the council investigation, we would start sort of looking into under the radar to see, is there something here? Then we may due an announce inspections to see, well, is there evidence to supports our hypothesis. And then eventually, we were send me an update if we find that we have a strong case.

It is of course for any company, very troublesome to be in the search slide of -- into trust investigation. So we are very careful to make sure that we find -- that we have a strong case. That doesn't mean that we have anything brought up preliminary, look in a case when we start it. But of course it has to be something serious. Otherwise we shouldn't do it.

GURA: There is a perception here, rightly or wrong, whether you're targeting American companies. I look back at the Google fine of recent weeks, a two billion Euros. It seems to give risk to those who think that you are going after American companies.

I mentioned a lot of what you're doing here when you trouble to the U.S. as explaining yourself in the process and what companies you're looking at. What do you say to somebody who does suggest that? Who feels as though you are unfairly seeking out of American companies through action?

VESTAGER: Well, first of all, I take this very seriously.

GURA: OK.

VESTAGER: Because by and as no place, no home in European anti-trust. It would be completely legitimatizing what we are doing because the point is that you have a single market. It's open for business but it's not open for bending the rules deciding the prices in the back office. And we also actually do have the statistics on our side when you look at mergers or anti-trust enforcement.

You do not find any kind of U.S. files. And that of course is a very, very important because it is not the flock of the company, the ownership of the company. It's the behavior in the markets that we concerned with.

GURA: All right, let's come back and talk a bit about Google in particular if we can lead much more. Much more with Commissioner Vestager coming up on Bloomberg Technology, this is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

CHANG: Welcome back to Bloomberg Technology, I'm Emily Chang. Let's get back to Washington with Bloomberg, David Gura who's standing by with the European Commissioner for Competition, Margrethe Vestager who was auditive to the United States. David, take it away.

GURA: Emily, thank you very much again. Let's get into Google a little bit here. I think a lot of people are good to serve that issue in particular. Google has 10 days as I understand to comply with the rule in the issue a few weeks back. What are you hoping to see by then? Have you seen a draft at this point? Do you have any sense of what Google's going to try to do with regard to shopping?

VESTAGER: Yes, now it seemed to be nine days ago. We took the decision that we have found that Google is dominant in the European market of general search. And that Google has been misusing this very strong and dominant position to promote itself and what the Google shopping products and to demotes competitors.

On average, you would find competitors on page four in a such result. And the U.S. can also sell, well, how often do I go there? While you were always finding glue shopping top left corner in the best placement. And the decision says that you have to try a principle of eco-treatment between go shopping and competitors because you're dominant.

And now, we talked to Google to figure out on how to this. Because this is the only way to make a remedy future proof, because assigned will change, screen sizes well change. Everything will change. But we still need this to be adhered to. So of course we remains to be seen how Google will leave up to this.

GURA: At Bloomberg, as reporting today that the Google is proposing certain option system. They would sell space to rival companies. And that something I proposed in 2013. That with another, can you confirm that that case that they uploaded out as an idea?

VESTAGER: Yes, we got the first draft to what they were thinking. I think in that two weeks ago. So we got to ruled outlined about what they're thinking. But the thing is that, it's not for us to prove, it is for Google to find a way to leave up to legislation. And this is of course, very important because if Google does not leave up to the decision then hen we will sort of investigating. Well, what is the situation and is competition still home (ph) so that consumers have best of choices that they would otherwise have.

GURA: So if come to 29th of September or however many days after you're not satisfied, but when does finding start? When do you begin to calculate and assess fines against Google if they hadn't meet the burden that you'd like them to meet?

VESTAGER: Well, actually we can sort of back date the fine so that it will start from the first day that we fine that there's been a none-compliance with the decision. So obviously if we find, for instance not compared -- market competitors that complain, the consumers may complain to say, well, this is not what it was supposed to be.

If we find a reason, we will start investigating and then we can free date the fines if we find that there is a bridge of the following up in the decision.

GURA: Can you give us any sense of the time table here with these two other Google cases. It was the absence case in the Android case as well. How close you to resolution of those two?

VESTAGER: Well, they are very different. The two cases because the absence case concerns placement they've asked on third party sites. And whether or not, that market was foreclosed. The Android cases, how Android is used to stay dominant also when we all go mobile. So that's sort of the experience from the box when you open the box of, you know, phone is a Google experience.

We treat both cases as high priority cases, but it's very difficult to say when we will be able to take a final decision.

GURA: And so which is farther long in the other, or they both kind of proceeding in tandem?

VESTAGER: Well, as I said, they are different, so we have two cases and I don't know if they're competing as well. But we will put a lot of efforts into this because it is important for all market participants to know what will be final decision.

GURA: Couple of months ago, we speak with Dara Khosrowshahi who is then the head of Expedia. He's now of course at Uber and he was expressing concern about Google with regard to travel services. When you look at the name (ph) with apparatus with this Google, are there other parts of the business that concern you with, it might lead to investigations?

VESTAGER: Well, we have quite a lot of the complaints on other verticals. And the thing is that with the Google shopping decision, having a stuff, of course, the Google is dominant in general search. And when the company is dominant, well obviously competition is already weakened a little if you hold 90 percent of the market, and this is where the special responsibility comes from that you should -- and you should used your powers and your own market on neighboring markets.

So this gives us another starting point looking at travel or locals. So in that respective, we still take a strong interest in Google behavior, and this now the markets.

GURA: I asked you the Apple tech's case it was that our companies to adjust. In the context of Google, you've let with this two billion Euro fine, have you seen that company begin to change its ways to work with your office to personal (ph) further finding of that company in particular. Is there a dialog between you and the company I guess? It's what I'm asking.

VESTAGER: Oh yes, there is a dialogue and I find them to be very, very professional. We don't agree on these issues, but I think it is important, no matter this agreement. In here, we are talking about a decision by the commission on the fine. I should say 2.4 billion Euros.

But it is s important to have a professional relationship because we want a change in market behavior to enable competition so that the market serve the consumer and then that hopefully, we can find a way.

GURA: Commissioner Vestager, thank you very much for giving us your time.

VESTAGER: Yes, thank you very much.

GURA: Appreciate it. Margrethe Vestager joined me here at the E.U. Delegations headquarters in Washington. Back to you Emily in San Francisco.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Jul 04, 2020( Foreign Policy: http://www.foreignpolicy.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Antitrust regulators are rarely well known outside of trade lobbies and industry circles. Not so Denmark's Margrethe Vestager, who may be the world's most famous corporate umpire. The European Union's competition commissioner, who began an unprecedented second term last November, is something of a global celebrity: She's a sought-after speaker, a female icon, and the person seen as most likely to rein in the unfettered dominance of the world's biggest technology firms.Vestager has made news with the huge fines for anti-competitive behavior she has leveled at companies such as Google and Apple. But those punitive measures were limited to Vestager's jurisdiction—the common European market—and represent only minor stumbles for the world's most powerful corporations.

That's why Vestager is redoubling her efforts and hoping other countries will follow her lead. foreign policy's Ravi Agrawal recently spoke with the Brussels-based Vestager about the future of regulation and competition in technology—and how the pandemic may have the strange effect of boosting her mission. Foreign Policy: I'll start with an easy question. How has the coronavirus pandemic affected your work? Margrethe Vestager: I have been busier than ever before. It has been very intense. Of course, this is nothing compared to all the people who are working in hospitals and saving lives. But from the moment we realized the enormous effects of the lockdown, we knew we had to make sure that first aid is available fast and that it's managed in such a way that our single market doesn't become completely fragmented. FP: Despite the historic job losses caused by the pandemic, the world's biggest tech firms all seem to be performing strongly in the stock market and further entrenching their market dominance. Does that worry you?MV: Well, it makes the regulatory approaches that we were considering even more urgent. Because we have now had a crash course, a full-scale experiment, in doing everything digitally: remote working, learning, socializing, even exercising. We see all the benefits that come with digital technologies. But the downsides are clearer now too. And that is a huge driver to make sure that a digital world is based on fairness and market access. We are pushing even more strongly now on the things we were already working on. We have ongoing investigations—some preliminary, some more advanced—into Amazon, Google, Facebook, and Apple. We have this sense of urgency to make sure that the innovative potential of digital technologies can be fulfilled and that we still have an open market where one can have a go at it. FP: There are all these theories about how the pandemic will change the world. What do you think it means for Big Tech and the fight to regulate it, not just in Europe but globally? MV: We now see so clearly how much digital technologies will be an integrated part of every aspect of our lives, that if anyone doubted the need to make sure that we have the right regulatory framework on technology, they must now be convinced that you cannot have a laissez-faire approach to something that's so involved in everything we do. I think that what was there already—a nascent public feeling in favor of regulation—is now growing and maturing much faster than it would otherwise have done. FP: But this could go two ways. One is that the pandemic boosts the appetite for regulation, but the other is that we could all become so much more reliant on some technologies and strengthen the market dominance of a few giant firms.MV: I tend to think the first scenario is more likely. You do not want to depend on someone who holds a lot of market power because you would want to have choice. You would want to have openings for newcomers. All of us now have experience with several ways of remote working—Skype, Webex, Zoom, and so on—and I find it quite intriguing to see the different facilities and really appreciate that there is choice. One product suits one situation; another product suits another situation. We would be served quite poorly if there were no choice. FP: While you have been lauded for fining companies such as Google and Apple for their antitrust and anti-competitive behavior, critics say those punishments are the equivalent of a mere parking ticket. MV: Yes. Our work here is still a work in progress. In these individual cases, the fine is a punishment for past illegal behavior. The second element in such a decision is a cease-and-desist order. And then we have the third element, which is a more restorative approach. Because what we have seen in Google's case is that even when the illegal behavior stops, that doesn't necessarily open the markets. Once you own a particular market, it takes a lot of effort to open that market for competitors. And this is why we also need a regulatory approach. We need to spell out more clearly to big digital gatekeepers that there are explicit dos and don'ts, and one of the obvious don'ts could be that you cannot promote yourself if you are a digital gatekeeper. FP: You're in Brussels, but the world's biggest tech firms are in the United States. Newer tech giants are emerging in Asia. Your role gives you power to regulate and fine companies for their business in Europe but not the rest of the world. Is there a way for countries to collaborate more on regulation and antitrust law? MV: Yes, I definitely think so. The interest in and the momentum of this cooperation is increasing. We have what we call the International Competition Network, where we discuss things like this. We have the General Data Protection Regulation [or GDPR, a landmark EU regulation on data protection and privacy]. And we also conduct outreach. For instance, the European Commission was in Addis Ababa to meet with the African Union Commission, and officials there were extremely interested in how to deal with privacy, competition, and making sure that markets are contestable. I think there is a very strong interest in these matters and an openness to not necessarily copy but to take inspiration as to what is needed to make sure that national and regional businesses get a fair chance in these markets. FP: How do you feel about companies such as Apple and Google creating contact-tracing apps? MV: For me, the fundamental thing to look at is not the company but the behavior of the company. No matter who develops a virus-tracking app, what is very important is that it comes with an open protocol that third parties can verify—and ensure that the app is not doing anything other than what it is said to be doing. And a decentralized system is ideal. But transparency is the main thing here. And of course, that companies enable the phones to work with different apps and across borders and operating systems. Otherwise these apps will not be useful. FP: Should surveillance be left to companies or countries? South Korea's Corona 100m app, for example, alerts users if they are within 100 meters of a coronavirus patient, but it has been criticized for being cavalier with patients' data. In India, the Aarogya Setu app has been downloaded by 120 million people, but that's mostly because the government made it mandatory. Obviously, neither of those cases are under your jurisdiction, but what do you make of them? MV: What has been important for us—and that in itself has been quite challenging—is for the European member states to come together on one approach. And that is slowly but surely happening. The more you can have a coordinated approach, the easier it is to make sure that different apps can work together. For us, the fundamental thing here has been whether or not people would trust the technology. Obviously it would have to be voluntary whether you would download such an app or not, and you would only make that choice if you trusted the technology to do what it says and nothing else—that it would respect your privacy. And this is very important for us because, just before the pandemic, we launched a European strategy on data and a white paper[1] on artificial intelligence, and the main takeaway here is to say we really believe in the benefits of digital technologies but only if we can trust these technologies to serve humans—and not just a few humans and not just a few companies. My guess is, because we can see how the GDPR has inspired other countries to take up similar measures, that citizens all around the world have a preoccupation with being able to trust their apps and what they do. People don't want to be part of the launch of a surveillance society for the next generation.FP: In many of your public speeches and interviews, you often talk about the concept of trust in society. In your 2017 TED Talk[2], for example, you described how a lack of trust in the market can lead to wider social dissatisfaction. Do you think that people should put their trust in these companies' intentions? MV: This is my sixth year as a law enforcer, and I see so many businesses that really make an effort to do things by the book and that struggle to innovate and to present the best possible service to their customers. And then I see a few companies—some that are returning customers where we keep receiving complaints—and we keep finding issues that give us reason to hand out big fines. I see both sides of this. I have a mixed feeling about this question because I also see the many good things and many companies that I would never have an issue with. FP: You have expressed concern[3] about Chinese companies taking over European ones, especially amid the pandemic, but your concern is primarily based on the notion that it may be unfair competition if the Chinese company is state-backed. But aren't those lines, in China and in other countries, murky? And if so, how do you deal with that? MV: We've reassessed our relationship with China and basically retired the idea that China is a developing economy. China is in some areas a partner, for instance when it comes to fighting climate change, but also a strategic competitor. And that has been informing a lot of the work that we've been doing. We're in the process of finalizing a white paper[4] on how to deal with foreign subsidiaries, both when it comes to reciprocity in market access and how to deal with state-owned or state-backed companies acquiring businesses within the single market. We felt a strong need to step up and act where we found a risk of unfair competition. The worry we have on acquisitions now is that there is a risk of a staggered global recovery. If some regions of the world recover faster than others, then there is the chance that some may think they should take advantage of it. We are very vigilant when it comes to that kind of risk.
