There are people right now, listen to BET, they still do not know that hands up don't shoot, it was a lie. Still, don't know that because they have not been told the truth.

So, there is a focused energy by this -- by the left, to get our -- to get our race upset, doing the things we're doing right now and not believing in our country and that's why the flag has to be one place we come together and say, listen, guys, we can disagree, we can figure out how to make this happen but the flags won't play as we stand together to recognize our country, the greatest place in history of mankind.

BARTIROMO: I agree with that. I agree with that.

BREWER: Yes. Amen to that.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BREWER: I mean, we all know we have issues.

BARTIROMO: You have to agree with that, Colin.

(CROSSTALK)

BREWER: We have to get over them. We have to get over them.

ALLRED: I agree with the sentiment that we are the greatest country. I would disagree that it has anything to do with BET or the business, anything to do with some kind of feeling on the left. I think that the black players feel like they need -- they have been ignored by both Democrats and Republicans and they're trying to get a message out there.

BARTIROMO: Do you think -- do you think this is working? Do you think standing -- getting to the knee is working in terms of impacting the issues that you are upset with?

ALLRED: I think that we are having a conversation about this right now because players started to take a knee. I think all of its country people are having conversations that they might not be having. And sometimes having uncomfortable conversations is a part of making progress.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Good point.

BREWER: What we need.

ALLRED: And I think that's something that's been initiated by this.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right. Great --

BREWER: Amen, Colin.

BARTIROMO: Great conversation, Colin, Burgess, Jack. Thank you so much.

ALLRED: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks for talking about the issues of the day.

OWENS: Thank you, guys.

BARTIROMO: We appreciate it. We'll see you soon, gentlemen. Thank you. Coming up. General Electric eyes major cost-cutting. The Wall Street Journal highlighting some of the excessive spending at the company including former CEO Jeff Immelt flying an empty jet next to his jet as a backup during his 16-year tenure when he travels. Just in case he's got mechanical failures. Stuart Varney will give us his take on the future of G.E. next. And then step aside Amazon, the technology-titan moves in Kohl's stores across the country. Our first look at the Amazon experience. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. An unlikely tie-up between two major retailers finally begins. Nicole Petallides on the floor of The New York Stock Exchange with the details. What a day yesterday was, a little different open today, huh, Nic?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right. And so, we're looking to the downside. But what records we keep setting, I mean, they'll just keep (INAUDIBLE) I guess. Taking a look at some of our movers this morning. Of course, part of this run-up has been because of great earnings, but I'm going to start with the story and that is the AmazonKohl's versus the Wal-Mart story. Amazon and Kohl's have now completed a tie-up intended to Kohl's and it will go to a lot of the Kohl's, 82 of the Kohl's. You're going to be able to go in there, into Kohl's, return your Amazon products. You'll even be able to try products out, gadgets, make purchases.

This is the way Amazon is going to take on Wal-Mart. Wal-Mart continues to grow and has Wal-Mart Express where you just basically on your phone say you're going to return it, you go into the store, you show your phone, you give the package, done 30 seconds. So, it is a battle. Now, let's get to those earnings we spoke of, Maria, watching Verizon and Travelers. Verizon looking to the upside today. This bright spot was the paying of the monthly bill subscribers. They added 274,000 phone subscribers, that beats the streets, that pushes Verizon up two percent and that will at least help the Dow, at least in part. They did see Verizon Fios subscribers dropping off.

Last but not least, the insurer, Travellers, the bright spot there was the strong underwriting. And in fact, that rose 4.2 percent to a record. The weak part was the catastrophe payouts, recording 700 million because of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma, but big picture, 59 percent drop in quarterly profit. It is fractionally higher this morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Nic, thank you so much, Nicole Petallides. Meanwhile, General Electric's new CEO making some big changes, John Flannery is reportedly expected to cut thousands of corporate-level jobs and scale back G.E.'s global structure. That's an addition to taking away company cars, canceling fancy executive retreats. We'll see what he does and what the announcement is tomorrow, apparently, there's going to be charges along with earnings tomorrow, when they report their third-quarter.

Joining us now, host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney with some thoughts on that. Kind of a crazy story was that, Stuart, that Jeff Immelt had an empty jet flying next to his jet on business trips just in case he had mechanical failure.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's a head-shaker. That is one of the worst pieces of P.R. for a leading business guy that I've seen in a long, long time. I'll repeat the story, Maria, if I may, I don't know why you've covered it already, I'm going to cover it, Jeff Immelt, CEO of G.E., often, not always, but often had a second empty corporate jet flying around after him -- he's in the first jet -- empty jet is the second jet, just in case there's mechanical failure or security problems with the first jet? That really is extraordinary. As you know, Maria -- look, I am fascinated by G.E. It was the stock of the last generation, and now it's not. They've got their profit margin declines, their financial business is largely gone, they made a bad bet on energy, the dividend is threatened, there's bad P.R. from the jets. And I'm questioning, Maria, maybe you can answer this one, is it a buy at $22.00 a share?

BARTIROMO: Yes. You know what, we had -- we had Scott Wren on early from Wells Fargo, and he's a real industrial guy. And he said he's looking at it. I mean, he didn't out-and-out say buy it at this level because we may see more weakness, but, yes, I think you make a good point, the stock has lost half of its value from the highs, Stu.

VARNEY: At $23.00 a share, it pays a four percent dividend. If that dividend is threatened and I'm told that it is and the stock goes down to $21.00 a share, say, just supposing it does, is it a buy at that point? I would say yes.

BARTIROMO: You're probably right, Stu. You're great at that. Stu, we'll see you in 10 minutes. Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour at 9:00 a.m. with Stuart Varney. We'll be right back, right here, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Two Navy pilots have been killed during a Navy Jet training exercise in Tennessee, this happened earlier this month. But what went wrong, is still in question. Lea is with us today. You're a former Navy fighter pilot, what have you learned?

GABRIELLE: Well, Maria, that specific crash, I spoke with the Navy about this, and they're still investigating, they don't know what caused it yet, but I did learn from the Navy that they were planning to do a low-level flight for that crash. Now, separate issue is the one I first reported here on this program back in April, when T-45 pilots were refusing to fly because of issues that they were having with their life support systems in the T-45, we've been continuing this investigation, and I visited Naval Air Station Patuxent River in Maryland. That's where research, development, test, and evaluations are done for naval aircraft. And it's the heart of where the Navy is trying to solve those problems with life support systems. Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DENNIS GORDGE, EXPERT, ALTITUDE SYSTEMS LABORATORY: This is a breathing regulator, which would control the flow of oxygen up through the hose to the mask, so every time you take a breath, this regulator would allow the oxygen to flow to the mask.

GABRIELLE: At this altitude systems laboratory, experts like Dennis Gordge are working with the Navy to address what are known as physiological episodes (INAUDIBLE) when pilots become impaired while flying, sometimes because they're breathing bad air. The issue has been jeopardizing flights in the T-45 trainer and the F-18 Hornet at an increasing rate.

When a jet has an oxygen problem, the Navy pulls the equipment out of the jet, and brings it here to Patuxent River. For example, this component is an oxygen concentrator from a T-45.

GORDGE: Each component of the system is evaluated for its own performance, this lab will put all those components together to look -- to see how it did as a system.

GABRIELLE: In fact, they can replicate the exact flight profile where a problem was reported to determine what went wrong with the systems.

GORDGE: So, this chamber is the simulated cockpit, and so this chamber would be the pressurized portion of the aircraft. This chamber, as you can see, has got two breathing simulators, mechanical breathing simulators.

REAR ADM. SELECT SARA JOYNER, PHYSIOLOGICAL EPISODES TEAM LEAD: We've collected a tremendous amount of data, now we're getting into the analysis and that's starting to inform some of the things that we think we need to address.

GABRIELLE: Navy Admiral Select Sara Joyner was handpicked by the top brass to address physiological episodes. She's been on the job since late August and says that they have been making modifications, like adding a new carbon monoxide removal tool and T-45s have a new warning system for pilots.

What was your feeling when you were asked to take over this, you know, being somebody who's been out there, flying jets and being in the midst of combat operations?

JOYNER: I think when I look at it is the trust and confidence given to me to do this mission. This is probably the most important thing that's going on in naval aviation. I couldn't feel anything other than a heavy responsibility combined with, you know, just really wanting to lean into the problem and get to work.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

GABRIELLE: T-45s that have been modified are flying again, although we've learned that pilots have reported six more incidents, Maria. F-18s are going to take longer.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. My thanks to a great panel. Thanks, everybody. Have a great day. Seize that day. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins now. Stuart, over to you.

VARNEY: I will seize it, Maria, thank you very much.

(LAUGHTER)

END

urn:contentItem:5VKT-36X1-DY0W-44PV-00000-00Market Milestone; Futures Under Pressure; ISIS PLots New Attack; Dangerous Fly-by; Goodell's Soft Stance; GE Eyes Cost Cuts; DOW CLoses2017-10-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:40ZLexisNexisMarket Milestone; Futures Under Pressure; ISIS PLots New Attack; Dangerous Fly-by; Goodell's Soft Stance; GE Eyes Cost Cuts; DOW CLosesLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good morning ladies, how are you? Thank you so much and good morning everybody. Happy Thursday to you. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, October 19th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Thirty years ago a market milestone and yesterday, a major market milestone as well.

(VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The DOW Jones Industrial Average closing above 23,000 for the first time ever yesterday. It was the f1st record close since President Trump took office. An amazing momentum market.

Earnings driving the gains yesterday, the optimism over tax cuts has underpinned market gains for months as well and we could be one step closer to it today. The Senate gears up for the budget vote later today. President Trump is calling this a once in a lifetime opportunity.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It will be the largest tax cut in the history of our country. I focus on tax cuts because it's such an important weapon to get our country really moving.

So we'll go from being one of the highest tax nations in the world to one of the lowest tax. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity in my opinion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We've got all of the updates coming up. Geopolitical tensions this morning however weighing on markets. Pulling things back from yesterday's all time high.

DOW Industrial expected to be down about 80 points at the opening of trading, down about a third of a percent, Nasdaq down two-thirds of a percent right now.

In Europe this morning, take a look at the action, all the major averages down as you see there with the FTSE100 down a quarter of a percent, the CAC Krones down almost half of a percent and the DAX Index down better than one half of one percent.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly lower with the exception of Japan which was up again taking a cue from the U.S., up half of a percent.

A brand new terrorism threat to report, the Department of Homeland Security is warning that ISIS is plotting another 9/11 style attack, details on this terrifying plan aiming to inflict mass casualties. We've got all the details.

And a scary scene at the German airport, an Air Berlin Jet does a dangerous fly-by with 200 passengers on board, the fallout from the active defiance coming up.

NFL Commission Roger Goodell refusing to take a tougher stance on anthem protests and nobody is happy with Goodell's comments even Colin Kaepernick, he fired back without opening his mouth. We'll tell you what he said.

General Electric eyes major cost cuts, "The Wall Street Journal" this morning reporting some of the excessive spending at the company including Former CEO Jeff Immelt flying an empty jet next to his jet as a back up during his 16-year tenure. Wow.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle is here. Kelly and Company Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly is here. And Rosecliff Capital CEO, Mike Murphy is here. Great to see you.

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER: Good morning. Great to be here.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Happy Thursday everybody.

GABRIELLE: We have 5,000 foot jump since President Trump took office in the DOW but this tax plan, man, I'll tell you, we're going to have to see what happens.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely, 23,000 and counting. I mean, come on.

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: And you know what's fascinating is actually Janet Yellen is due to have a meeting today at the White House with President Trump.

And so whatever happens at the Fed and whoever they pick next is going to have significant impacts on the markets and one of the reasons why you can see that is because the Fed has been so accommodative to this market.

You've seen asset inflation, I mean valuations are at all time highs. So it's a fascinating aspect because Secretary MNuchin has reported that he doesn't like Kevin Warsh because he think he could royal markets, right?

He wasn't for quantitative using, he actually was very adamant against it. And so Jerome Powell is more accommodative.

BARTIROMO: We may know this week or next who the president decides on, we're going to get to all of that coming up.

But first, our top story this hour and that is the market milestone, 23,000. The DOW Industrial closed above the 23,000 mark for the first time ever yesterday. Treasury Secretary Steven MNuchin though made an important comment throughout the day warning that all of those games could be in jeopardy should Congress fail to pass tax reform.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY TEXT:

There is no question that the rally in the stock market has based into it reasonably high expectations of us getting tax cuts and tax reform done. It also has based into it optimism on regulatory relief which they begun to see and there's expectations. So I think to the extent we get the tax deal done, the stock market will go up higher but there's no question in my mind if we don't get it done, you're going to see a reversal of the significant amount of these gains.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: sounds about right, the Senate is expected to vote today on a budget that would allow the Chamber to pass a tax bill with just 51 votes instead of the 60 needed for major legislation.

Joining us right now to talk more about that is Former Chief Strategist for Texas Senator Ted Cruz, his senate and president campaign, Jason Johnson is with us along with Former Deputy Secretary of Labor in the Obama Administration, now a Senior Fellow at the University of Virginia Miller Center, Chris Liu. Good to see you both gentlemen, Thank you so much for joining us this morning.

CHRIS LIU, FORMER DEPUTY SECRETARY OF LABOR, OBAMA ADMINISTRATION: Thank you.

JASON JOHNSON, FORMER CRUZ CAMPAIGN CHIEF STRATEGIST: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: So Jason, in that same interview, the Treasury Secretary made those comments about the market, he offered this, an absolutely guarantee that a tax overhaul would be sign into law by the end of this year. Is that a reasonable time table? Do you think they will get this done?

JOHNSON: Well certainly if you look at the performance this year with other major pieces of legislation it doesn't seem reasonable. But I understand why the Secretary is saying what he's saying.

There is an absolute expectation that this has to be done in the political market if you will. And so I'm not incredibly optimistic that it happens by the end of the year. There certainly seems to be a mixed message coming from some leaders on the Hill as to whether or not the deadline is the end of the year. But whether it's the end of the year or after the first of the year, it must happen.

BARTIROMO: Chris, do you agree with that that it must happen and that it will happen?

LIU: I agree with Senator McConnell who said it's more important that we get it right instead of just running this through. And I think it's important to look at the details here and we don't really know yet percentage is going to go to the super wealthy, how it's going to add to the deficit whether it's really going to fix the idiosyncrasies in the tax code right now.

And so putting it on an artificial deadline does not bode well for coming up with good policy and that's really what the market wants to see right now. They really want to see the once in a generation tax reform proposal, not another giveaway that just goes to the super wealthy.

KELLY: Yes, Chris considering -- it's Kevin Kelly here. Considering you spent time in the White House especially with President Obama, do you think it's appropriate for a cabinet secretaries or anybody in this administration to be talking about the impact on stock markets given that they should be focusing on policy and talking about the implements, what it could do to the real economy as opposed to really focusing on markets that should do whatever they should be doing?

LIU: That's exactly right. It's one of the reasons why we in the Obama Administration didn't talk about the stock market even though we had significant gains as well because the market goes up and unfortunately it goes down as well.

And it goes up or down for reasons that have nothing to do with Washington. And if I were Secretary MNuchin, I would probably take my cues from the leaders on the Hill as to what the timing should be.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, I know. I think that's a good point but at the same time, $5.3 trillion in market value doesn't come out of air. It's clear that the market value that we've seen in these gains is partly due to optimism over what President Trump is doing.

He's rolled back an incredible amount of regulation and they're expecting tax reform. Are you saying $5.3 trillion in market value is just a coincidence?

LIU: Well I would say that it's based on the expectation something's happening. This is a recovery, economic recovery that began in early 2010 and we've had essentially seven straight years of economic growth.

There have been rollbacks of regulations but there hasn't been this significant economic change that Donald Trump has promised yet. So a lot of this is --

BARTIROMO: Well, we did see a 3.1 percent GDP the other day and GDP was averaging about one and a half percent under President Obama. So -- I mean there's something to it that the economy is definitely better.

BARTIROMO: So, what about the way viewers have reacted "Monday Night Football" ratings have dropped to a new low, the Colts-Titans game drew an average of roughly eight million viewers, that was down 18 percent -- 18- 1/2 percent from the previous week's game. I mean, Burgess, do you think that tonight's game between the Chiefs and the Raiders will reverse the downward trend or are we are going to see viewers react negatively to the players doing their politics on the field?

OWENS: Well, I think the last time -- that was a very good point, these players truly do believe in what they're doing, here is -- here is a reason, why do they believe this? It's because we have a black entertainment -- a network that's pushing this anti-American, anti-flag, anti-white scenario, and this -- and this been on purpose guys. 15 years we've been hearing this. So these kids coming out, they truly do not believe in our country think everything is going wrong. There are people right now, listen to BET, they still do not know that hands up don't shoot, it was a lie. Still, don't know that because they have not been told the truth.

So, there is a focused energy by this -- by the left, to get our -- to get our race upset, doing the things we're doing right now and not believing in our country and that's why the flag has to be one place we come together and say, listen, guys, we can disagree, we can figure out how to make this happen but the flags won't play as we stand together to recognize our country, the greatest place in history of mankind.

BARTIROMO: I agree with that. I agree with that.

BREWER: Yes. Amen to that.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BREWER: I mean, we all know we have issues.

BARTIROMO: You have to agree with that, Colin.

(CROSSTALK)

BREWER: We have to get over them. We have to get over them.

ALLRED: I agree with the sentiment that we are the greatest country. I would disagree that it has anything to do with BET or the business, anything to do with some kind of feeling on the left. I think that the black players feel like they need -- they have been ignored by both Democrats and Republicans and they're trying to get a message out there.

BARTIROMO: Do you think -- do you think this is working? Do you think standing -- getting to the knee is working in terms of impacting the issues that you are upset with?

ALLRED: I think that we are having a conversation about this right now because players started to take a knee. I think all of its country people are having conversations that they might not be having. And sometimes having uncomfortable conversations is a part of making progress.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Good point.

BREWER: What we need.

ALLRED: And I think that's something that's been initiated by this.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right. Great --

BREWER: Amen, Colin.

BARTIROMO: Great conversation, Colin, Burgess, Jack. Thank you so much.

ALLRED: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks for talking about the issues of the day.

OWENS: Thank you, guys.

BARTIROMO: We appreciate it. We'll see you soon, gentlemen. Thank you. Coming up. General Electric eyes major cost-cutting. The Wall Street Journal highlighting some of the excessive spending at the company including former CEO Jeff Immelt flying an empty jet next to his jet as a backup during his 16-year tenure when he travels. Just in case he's got mechanical failures. Stuart Varney will give us his take on the future of G.E. next. And then step aside Amazon, the technology-titan moves in Kohl's stores across the country. Our first look at the Amazon experience. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. An unlikely tie-up between two major retailers finally begins. Nicole Petallides on the floor of The New York Stock Exchange with the details. What a day yesterday was, a little different open today, huh, Nic?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right. And so, we're looking to the downside. But what records we keep setting, I mean, they'll just keep (INAUDIBLE) I guess. Taking a look at some of our movers this morning. Of course, part of this run-up has been because of great earnings, but I'm going to start with the story and that is the AmazonKohl's versus the Wal-Mart story. Amazon and Kohl's have now completed a tie-up intended to Kohl's and it will go to a lot of the Kohl's, 82 of the Kohl's. You're going to be able to go in there, into Kohl's, return your Amazon products. You'll even be able to try products out, gadgets, make purchases.

This is the way Amazon is going to take on Wal-Mart. Wal-Mart continues to grow and has Wal-Mart Express where you just basically on your phone say you're going to return it, you go into the store, you show your phone, you give the package, done 30 seconds. So, it is a battle. Now, let's get to those earnings we spoke of, Maria, watching Verizon and Travelers. Verizon looking to the upside today. This bright spot was the paying of the monthly bill subscribers. They added 274,000 phone subscribers, that beats the streets, that pushes Verizon up two percent and that will at least help the Dow, at least in part. They did see Verizon Fios subscribers dropping off.

Last but not least, the insurer, Travellers, the bright spot there was the strong underwriting. And in fact, that rose 4.2 percent to a record. The weak part was the catastrophe payouts, recording 700 million because of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma, but big picture, 59 percent drop in quarterly profit. It is fractionally higher this morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Nic, thank you so much, Nicole Petallides. Meanwhile, General Electric's new CEO making some big changes, John Flannery is reportedly expected to cut thousands of corporate-level jobs and scale back G.E.'s global structure. That's an addition to taking away company cars, canceling fancy executive retreats. We'll see what he does and what the announcement is tomorrow, apparently, there's going to be charges along with earnings tomorrow, when they report their third-quarter.

Joining us now, host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney with some thoughts on that. Kind of a crazy story was that, Stuart, that Jeff Immelt had an empty jet flying next to his jet on business trips just in case he had mechanical failure.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's a head-shaker. That is one of the worst pieces of P.R. for a leading business guy that I've seen in a long, long time. I'll repeat the story, Maria, if I may, I don't know why you've covered it already, I'm going to cover it, Jeff Immelt, CEO of G.E., often, not always, but often had a second empty corporate jet flying around after him -- he's in the first jet -- empty jet is the second jet, just in case there's mechanical failure or security problems with the first jet? That really is extraordinary. As you know, Maria -- look, I am fascinated by G.E. It was the stock of the last generation, and now it's not. They've got their profit margin declines, their financial business is largely gone, they made a bad bet on energy, the dividend is threatened, there's bad P.R. from the jets. And I'm questioning, Maria, maybe you can answer this one, is it a buy at $22.00 a share?

BARTIROMO: Yes. You know what, we had -- we had Scott Wren on early from Wells Fargo, and he's a real industrial guy. And he said he's looking at it. I mean, he didn't out-and-out say buy it at this level because we may see more weakness, but, yes, I think you make a good point, the stock has lost half of its value from the highs, Stu.

VARNEY: At $23.00 a share, it pays a four percent dividend. If that dividend is threatened and I'm told that it is and the stock goes down to $21.00 a share, say, just supposing it does, is it a buy at that point? I would say yes.

BARTIROMO: You're probably right, Stu. You're great at that. Stu, we'll see you in 10 minutes. Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour at 9:00 a.m. with Stuart Varney. We'll be right back, right here, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Two Navy pilots have been killed during a Navy Jet training exercise in Tennessee, this happened earlier this month. But what went wrong, is still in question. Lea is with us today. You're a former Navy fighter pilot, what have you learned?

GABRIELLE: Well, Maria, that specific crash, I spoke with the Navy about this, and they're still investigating, they don't know what caused it yet, but I did learn from the Navy that they were planning to do a low-level flight for that crash. Now, separate issue is the one I first reported here on this program back in April, when T-45 pilots were refusing to fly because of issues that they were having with their life support systems in the T-45, we've been continuing this investigation, and I visited Naval Air Station Patuxent River in Maryland. That's where research, development, test, and evaluations are done for naval aircraft. And it's the heart of where the Navy is trying to solve those problems with life support systems. Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DENNIS GORDGE, EXPERT, ALTITUDE SYSTEMS LABORATORY: This is a breathing regulator, which would control the flow of oxygen up through the hose to the mask, so every time you take a breath, this regulator would allow the oxygen to flow to the mask.

GABRIELLE: At this altitude systems laboratory, experts like Dennis Gordge are working with the Navy to address what are known as physiological episodes (INAUDIBLE) when pilots become impaired while flying, sometimes because they're breathing bad air. The issue has been jeopardizing flights in the T-45 trainer and the F-18 Hornet at an increasing rate.

When a jet has an oxygen problem, the Navy pulls the equipment out of the jet, and brings it here to Patuxent River. For example, this component is an oxygen concentrator from a T-45.

GORDGE: Each component of the system is evaluated for its own performance, this lab will put all those components together to look -- to see how it did as a system.

GABRIELLE: In fact, they can replicate the exact flight profile where a problem was reported to determine what went wrong with the systems.

GORDGE: So, this chamber is the simulated cockpit, and so this chamber would be the pressurized portion of the aircraft. This chamber, as you can see, has got two breathing simulators, mechanical breathing simulators.

REAR ADM. SELECT SARA JOYNER, PHYSIOLOGICAL EPISODES TEAM LEAD: We've collected a tremendous amount of data, now we're getting into the analysis and that's starting to inform some of the things that we think we need to address.

GABRIELLE: Navy Admiral Select Sara Joyner was handpicked by the top brass to address physiological episodes. She's been on the job since late August and says that they have been making modifications, like adding a new carbon monoxide removal tool and T-45s have a new warning system for pilots.

What was your feeling when you were asked to take over this, you know, being somebody who's been out there, flying jets and being in the midst of combat operations?

JOYNER: I think when I look at it is the trust and confidence given to me to do this mission. This is probably the most important thing that's going on in naval aviation. I couldn't feel anything other than a heavy responsibility combined with, you know, just really wanting to lean into the problem and get to work.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

GABRIELLE: T-45s that have been modified are flying again, although we've learned that pilots have reported six more incidents, Maria. F-18s are going to take longer.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. My thanks to a great panel. Thanks, everybody. Have a great day. Seize that day. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins now. Stuart, over to you.

VARNEY: I will seize it, Maria, thank you very much.

(LAUGHTER)

END

urn:contentItem:5VKT-36X1-DY0W-44PR-00000-00Market Milestone; Futures Under Pressure; ISIS PLots New Attack; Dangerous Fly-by; Goodell's Soft Stance; GE Eyes Cost Cuts; DOW CLoses2017-10-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:40ZLexisNexisMarket Milestone; Futures Under Pressure; ISIS PLots New Attack; Dangerous Fly-by; Goodell's Soft Stance; GE Eyes Cost Cuts; DOW CLosesLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good morning ladies, how are you? Thank you so much and good morning everybody. Happy Thursday to you. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, October 19th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Thirty years ago a market milestone and yesterday, a major market milestone as well.

(VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The DOW Jones Industrial Average closing above 23,000 for the first time ever yesterday. It was the f1st record close since President Trump took office. An amazing momentum market.

Earnings driving the gains yesterday, the optimism over tax cuts has underpinned market gains for months as well and we could be one step closer to it today. The Senate gears up for the budget vote later today. President Trump is calling this a once in a lifetime opportunity.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It will be the largest tax cut in the history of our country. I focus on tax cuts because it's such an important weapon to get our country really moving.

So we'll go from being one of the highest tax nations in the world to one of the lowest tax. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity in my opinion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We've got all of the updates coming up. Geopolitical tensions this morning however weighing on markets. Pulling things back from yesterday's all time high.

DOW Industrial expected to be down about 80 points at the opening of trading, down about a third of a percent, Nasdaq down two-thirds of a percent right now.

In Europe this morning, take a look at the action, all the major averages down as you see there with the FTSE100 down a quarter of a percent, the CAC Krones down almost half of a percent and the DAX Index down better than one half of one percent.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly lower with the exception of Japan which was up again taking a cue from the U.S., up half of a percent.

A brand new terrorism threat to report, the Department of Homeland Security is warning that ISIS is plotting another 9/11 style attack, details on this terrifying plan aiming to inflict mass casualties. We've got all the details.

And a scary scene at the German airport, an Air Berlin Jet does a dangerous fly-by with 200 passengers on board, the fallout from the active defiance coming up.

NFL Commission Roger Goodell refusing to take a tougher stance on anthem protests and nobody is happy with Goodell's comments even Colin Kaepernick, he fired back without opening his mouth. We'll tell you what he said.

General Electric eyes major cost cuts, "The Wall Street Journal" this morning reporting some of the excessive spending at the company including Former CEO Jeff Immelt flying an empty jet next to his jet as a back up during his 16-year tenure. Wow.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle is here. Kelly and Company Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly is here. And Rosecliff Capital CEO, Mike Murphy is here. Great to see you.

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER: Good morning. Great to be here.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Happy Thursday everybody.

GABRIELLE: We have 5,000 foot jump since President Trump took office in the DOW but this tax plan, man, I'll tell you, we're going to have to see what happens.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely, 23,000 and counting. I mean, come on.

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: And you know what's fascinating is actually Janet Yellen is due to have a meeting today at the White House with President Trump.

And so whatever happens at the Fed and whoever they pick next is going to have significant impacts on the markets and one of the reasons why you can see that is because the Fed has been so accommodative to this market.

You've seen asset inflation, I mean valuations are at all time highs. So it's a fascinating aspect because Secretary MNuchin has reported that he doesn't like Kevin Warsh because he think he could royal markets, right?

He wasn't for quantitative using, he actually was very adamant against it. And so Jerome Powell is more accommodative.

BARTIROMO: We may know this week or next who the president decides on, we're going to get to all of that coming up.

But first, our top story this hour and that is the market milestone, 23,000. The DOW Industrial closed above the 23,000 mark for the first time ever yesterday. Treasury Secretary Steven MNuchin though made an important comment throughout the day warning that all of those games could be in jeopardy should Congress fail to pass tax reform.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY TEXT:

There is no question that the rally in the stock market has based into it reasonably high expectations of us getting tax cuts and tax reform done. It also has based into it optimism on regulatory relief which they begun to see and there's expectations. So I think to the extent we get the tax deal done, the stock market will go up higher but there's no question in my mind if we don't get it done, you're going to see a reversal of the significant amount of these gains.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: sounds about right, the Senate is expected to vote today on a budget that would allow the Chamber to pass a tax bill with just 51 votes instead of the 60 needed for major legislation.

Joining us right now to talk more about that is Former Chief Strategist for Texas Senator Ted Cruz, his senate and president campaign, Jason Johnson is with us along with Former Deputy Secretary of Labor in the Obama Administration, now a Senior Fellow at the University of Virginia Miller Center, Chris Liu. Good to see you both gentlemen, Thank you so much for joining us this morning.

CHRIS LIU, FORMER DEPUTY SECRETARY OF LABOR, OBAMA ADMINISTRATION: Thank you.

JASON JOHNSON, FORMER CRUZ CAMPAIGN CHIEF STRATEGIST: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: So Jason, in that same interview, the Treasury Secretary made those comments about the market, he offered this, an absolutely guarantee that a tax overhaul would be sign into law by the end of this year. Is that a reasonable time table? Do you think they will get this done?

JOHNSON: Well certainly if you look at the performance this year with other major pieces of legislation it doesn't seem reasonable. But I understand why the Secretary is saying what he's saying.

There is an absolute expectation that this has to be done in the political market if you will. And so I'm not incredibly optimistic that it happens by the end of the year. There certainly seems to be a mixed message coming from some leaders on the Hill as to whether or not the deadline is the end of the year. But whether it's the end of the year or after the first of the year, it must happen.

BARTIROMO: Chris, do you agree with that that it must happen and that it will happen?

LIU: I agree with Senator McConnell who said it's more important that we get it right instead of just running this through. And I think it's important to look at the details here and we don't really know yet percentage is going to go to the super wealthy, how it's going to add to the deficit whether it's really going to fix the idiosyncrasies in the tax code right now.

And so putting it on an artificial deadline does not bode well for coming up with good policy and that's really what the market wants to see right now. They really want to see the once in a generation tax reform proposal, not another giveaway that just goes to the super wealthy.

KELLY: Yes, Chris considering -- it's Kevin Kelly here. And then, there's Spain, the government there is set to activate an emergency measure to take control of Catalonia, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, Maria. So, Spain's government calling a special cabinet for the weekend to activate this measure -- it allows for the central government to take over the semiautonomous power of any of the country's17 regions. Now, this comes after Catalonia's leader said, Separatist lawmakers, can vote in favor of declaration of independence. The measure has never been used in the four decades since democracy was restored in Spain.

Well, an Air Berlin pilot is in big trouble. He performed a risky flying stunt with 200 passengers aboard. You're watching the video of it right now. Reports say he buzzed Dusseldorf Airport terminal in a maneuver that was met to mark the bankrupt last Trans-Atlantic flight. Well, a pilot of another told Reuters that a go-around should only be performed for its operations, or safety aviation officials are looking at this video and looking into this incident.

Well, Blue Apron, they are tightening their belt. The company has laid out six percent of the workforce, that's about 300 workers, as part of a company or organization. Blue Apron has struggled since it went public back in June with its stock price cut in half since then. Competition from a rival, a big one that would-be Amazon. There is the year to date chart, you can see it on your screen.

Meanwhile, Sea World is laying off 350 workers due to low attendance at its parks -- mainly in Orlando and San Diego. They've been trying to rebuild the brand solving protests over its treatment of their killer whales. Shares of Sea World, down more than 34 percent year to date.

And then, finally this, Snickers are getting a facelift, actually three facelifts. The candy company announcing they're going to release a line of three new flavors to combat a number of different, well, emotional issues. Feeling irritable, wimpy, indecisive? Well, they've got the cure. These three bars: espresso, fiery, and salty and sweet, Maria. Right now, I think I want the espresso. I'm a little tired.

BARTIROMO: Wow! Yes, the expresso sounds good.

KELLY: Thanks to wimpy for fiery, right? Like, I like spicy stuff, but it doesn't mean that I'm a wimp.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: He's taking it personally.

GABRIELLE: So -- but personally, I'm really concerned about the espresso one, because if you're irritable, I think the last thing you actually need is to have some more caffeine. More caffeine. I always like those names, though. I actually find that really attractive. When you're in a store and you're looking at candy and you're like, yes, you know, I kind of feel irritable.

BARTIROMO: But do you buy right there? Or will you buy it because of that?

GABRIELLE: No. Only if I really want it.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell, speaking out over the national anthem protest. What he said to players and how they're reacting, next. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Well, it's a big night at Wrigley Field last night. The Cubs fought for their playoff lives and they survived. Jared Max with the highlights, Jared.

So, there will be a game 5. Tonight, at Wrigley Field, the Cubs pick Jose Montana. The Dodgers' Clayton Kershaw L.A. leads three games to one.

New York Yankees rookie, Aaron Judge, a hero again last night. A third- inning double off Astros Ace, Dallas Keuchel, gave the Yanks a 2-0 lead. Then, at the seventh inning, fellow baby bomber, Gary Sanchez, smashes a solo home run against Brad Peacock -- third home run this postseason for Sanchez. Yankees' finally got reminisce its Dallas Keuchel and Masahiro Tanaka. 7-shutout innings, 5-0, Yanks win.

Series goes back to Houston where the Astros won the first two games. Here's to start, Justin Verlander tomorrow night, and Yankees turn to Luis Severino. Yanks, one win from their 41st American League pennant.

Hey, you know when somebody says, I'm not asking you, I'm telling you. Well, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell announced the opposite yesterday, regarding players choices to stand or kneel for the national anthem.

ROGER GOODELL, COMMISSIONER FOR THE NFL: Everyone should stand for the national anthem, that's an important part of our policy. The Seahawks' Michael Bennett isn't interested in discussing how to fix these social issues. While the NFL team owners are trying to.

Why? He says, "I don't think we can work alongside them until we address that issue. I think the issue with Kaepernick is the start to a conversation. If they want us to be open to what they want, the dialogue, then that's something that needs to be on the table right there." So, Kaepernick first and then the issues.

Some kneel, some protests, some put their money where their mouth is, like the Philadelphia Eagles' Chris Long who has supported teammates protesting the national anthem but is also doing something else. Chris Long of the Eagles, who had donated his first six-game paychecks this season to fund two scholarships at a prep school in Charlottesville where he grew up is now donating the rest of his 2017 NFL salary. Ten more paychecks to help fund education to make it for folks who are -- don't get the opportunities in certain cities -- ten weeks of paychecks going to this in cities of St. Louis, Boston and also Philadelphia.

BARTIROMO: That is great.

KELLY: Leading by example.

GABRIELLE: Football has a 10 for Tomorrow campaign. Good on him for that.

BARTIROMO: Hey, go Yanks!

MURPHY: Yes, this should be the go Yanks.

MAX: Some Mets fans started this as soon when the Yankees beat the Mets, and he got Wednesday missing. Somehow, the Yankees do this.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good morning ladies, how are you? Thank you so much and good morning everybody. Happy Thursday to you. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, October 19th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Thirty years ago a market milestone and yesterday, a major market milestone as well.

(VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The DOW Jones Industrial Average closing above 23,000 for the first time ever yesterday. It was the f1st record close since President Trump took office. An amazing momentum market.

Earnings driving the gains yesterday, the optimism over tax cuts has underpinned market gains for months as well and we could be one step closer to it today. The Senate gears up for the budget vote later today. President Trump is calling this a once in a lifetime opportunity.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It will be the largest tax cut in the history of our country. I focus on tax cuts because it's such an important weapon to get our country really moving.

So we'll go from being one of the highest tax nations in the world to one of the lowest tax. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity in my opinion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We've got all of the updates coming up. Geopolitical tensions this morning however weighing on markets. Pulling things back from yesterday's all time high.

DOW Industrial expected to be down about 80 points at the opening of trading, down about a third of a percent, Nasdaq down two-thirds of a percent right now.

In Europe this morning, take a look at the action, all the major averages down as you see there with the FTSE100 down a quarter of a percent, the CAC Krones down almost half of a percent and the DAX Index down better than one half of one percent.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly lower with the exception of Japan which was up again taking a cue from the U.S., up half of a percent.

A brand new terrorism threat to report, the Department of Homeland Security is warning that ISIS is plotting another 9/11 style attack, details on this terrifying plan aiming to inflict mass casualties. We've got all the details.

And a scary scene at the German airport, an Air Berlin Jet does a dangerous fly-by with 200 passengers on board, the fallout from the active defiance coming up.

NFL Commission Roger Goodell refusing to take a tougher stance on anthem protests and nobody is happy with Goodell's comments even Colin Kaepernick, he fired back without opening his mouth. We'll tell you what he said.

General Electric eyes major cost cuts, "The Wall Street Journal" this morning reporting some of the excessive spending at the company including Former CEO Jeff Immelt flying an empty jet next to his jet as a back up during his 16-year tenure. Wow.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle is here. Kelly and Company Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly is here. And Rosecliff Capital CEO, Mike Murphy is here. Great to see you.

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER: Good morning. Great to be here.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Happy Thursday everybody.

GABRIELLE: We have 5,000 foot jump since President Trump took office in the DOW but this tax plan, man, I'll tell you, we're going to have to see what happens.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely, 23,000 and counting. I mean, come on.

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: And you know what's fascinating is actually Janet Yellen is due to have a meeting today at the White House with President Trump.

And so whatever happens at the Fed and whoever they pick next is going to have significant impacts on the markets and one of the reasons why you can see that is because the Fed has been so accommodative to this market.

You've seen asset inflation, I mean valuations are at all time highs. So it's a fascinating aspect because Secretary MNuchin has reported that he doesn't like Kevin Warsh because he think he could royal markets, right?

He wasn't for quantitative using, he actually was very adamant against it. And so Jerome Powell is more accommodative.

BARTIROMO: We may know this week or next who the president decides on, we're going to get to all of that coming up.

But first, our top story this hour and that is the market milestone, 23,000. The DOW Industrial closed above the 23,000 mark for the first time ever yesterday. Treasury Secretary Steven MNuchin though made an important comment throughout the day warning that all of those games could be in jeopardy should Congress fail to pass tax reform.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY TEXT:

There is no question that the rally in the stock market has based into it reasonably high expectations of us getting tax cuts and tax reform done. It also has based into it optimism on regulatory relief which they begun to see and there's expectations. So I think to the extent we get the tax deal done, the stock market will go up higher but there's no question in my mind if we don't get it done, you're going to see a reversal of the significant amount of these gains.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: sounds about right, the Senate is expected to vote today on a budget that would allow the Chamber to pass a tax bill with just 51 votes instead of the 60 needed for major legislation.

Joining us right now to talk more about that is Former Chief Strategist for Texas Senator Ted Cruz, his senate and president campaign, Jason Johnson is with us along with Former Deputy Secretary of Labor in the Obama Administration, now a Senior Fellow at the University of Virginia Miller Center, Chris Liu. Good to see you both gentlemen, Thank you so much for joining us this morning.

CHRIS LIU, FORMER DEPUTY SECRETARY OF LABOR, OBAMA ADMINISTRATION: Thank you.

JASON JOHNSON, FORMER CRUZ CAMPAIGN CHIEF STRATEGIST: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: So Jason, in that same interview, the Treasury Secretary made those comments about the market, he offered this, an absolutely guarantee that a tax overhaul would be sign into law by the end of this year. Is that a reasonable time table? Do you think they will get this done?

JOHNSON: Well certainly if you look at the performance this year with other major pieces of legislation it doesn't seem reasonable. But I understand why the Secretary is saying what he's saying.

There is an absolute expectation that this has to be done in the political market if you will. And so I'm not incredibly optimistic that it happens by the end of the year. There certainly seems to be a mixed message coming from some leaders on the Hill as to whether or not the deadline is the end of the year. But whether it's the end of the year or after the first of the year, it must happen.

BARTIROMO: Chris, do you agree with that that it must happen and that it will happen?

LIU: I agree with Senator McConnell who said it's more important that we get it right instead of just running this through. And I think it's important to look at the details here and we don't really know yet percentage is going to go to the super wealthy, how it's going to add to the deficit whether it's really going to fix the idiosyncrasies in the tax code right now.

And so putting it on an artificial deadline does not bode well for coming up with good policy and that's really what the market wants to see right now. They really want to see the once in a generation tax reform proposal, not another giveaway that just goes to the super wealthy.

KELLY: Yes, Chris considering -- it's Kevin Kelly here. Considering you spent time in the White House especially with President Obama, do you think it's appropriate for a cabinet secretaries or anybody in this administration to be talking about the impact on stock markets given that they should be focusing on policy and talking about the implements, what it could do to the real economy as opposed to really focusing on markets that should do whatever they should be doing?

LIU: That's exactly right. It's one of the reasons why we in the Obama Administration didn't talk about the stock market even though we had significant gains as well because the market goes up and unfortunately it goes down as well.

And it goes up or down for reasons that have nothing to do with Washington. And if I were Secretary MNuchin, I would probably take my cues from the leaders on the Hill as to what the timing should be.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, I know. I think that's a good point but at the same time, $5.3 trillion in market value doesn't come out of air. It's clear that the market value that we've seen in these gains is partly due to optimism over what President Trump is doing.

He's rolled back an incredible amount of regulation and they're expecting tax reform. Are you saying $5.3 trillion in market value is just a coincidence?

LIU: Well I would say that it's based on the expectation something's happening. This is a recovery, economic recovery that began in early 2010 and we've had essentially seven straight years of economic growth.

There have been rollbacks of regulations but there hasn't been this significant economic change that Donald Trump has promised yet. So a lot of this is --

BARTIROMO: Well, we did see a 3.1 percent GDP the other day and GDP was averaging about one and a half percent under President Obama. So -- I mean there's something to it that the economy is definitely better.

You're (INAUDIBLE) in small business, do you see that Mike Murphy? Do you see things getting better? Yes.

MURPHY: Absolutely. We see small business optimism out there, we see startups, we see companies that are looking to disrupt existing industries coming out hiring people, raising money, going out and creating -- using technology to make our lives better. So I think right now the optimism that we see nationwide is something we haven't seen in a long time.

BARTIROMO: Jason, let me ask you this, in terms of this bill, if it gets done in the first quarter, do you think that still has a positive impact? If we don't see a bill on the president's desk by Thanksgiving, this is going to be a problem for certainly into the 2018 election for the republicans.

JOHNSON: Sure. Going back to the comment earlier that we shouldn't have artificial deadlines. I don't believe getting this done by the end of the year or seeing that we need to get it done by the end of the year is an artificial deadline because we know historically that very few things happen in election year.

And as we all know, next year is an election year. So Maria, into the first quarter, maybe so but we know that you get much passed the first quarter these guys don't like to do much in an election year.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And you're right, if they don't get it done maybe that's -- they should move out because this is something that the American people want, Lea Gabrielle.

GABRIELLE: Yes. Chris, Senator Schumer said our republican friends are trying to hide what's in the tax bill that they don't want people to know.

Is this just resistance sort of popping up already from the democrats on this obstructionist because really tax reform is good for all Americans right now, is it?

LIU: A hundred percent agree tax reform is good. What we have seen so far is simply tax cuts and some of the initial estimates are that becoming 50 to 80 percent of the benefits would go to the top one percent. Look --

BARTIROMO: That's not true. That's just not true. I don't want to spew out nonsense because 80 percent of the tax reform package going to the top one percent is nonsense.

LIU: An important issue to get right. For instance, it's the state and local tax deduction which is going to affect a lot republican members and understanding the details of that is not just resistance, it's actually trying to make sure that this is legitimate tax reform and there are so many issues. This is why this is hard and it's hard to get it right.

BARTIROMO: You're talking about a corporate rate of 20 percent. If you see the corporate rate go down from 35 percent to 20 percent, that will be a positive for corporations and the idea is is that they are going to reinvest in higher (INAUDIBLE)

KELLY: It's small businesses.

BARTIROMO: Small business with 25 percent pass through rate, same thing down from 39.6. So this is a significant move. He's also talking about three brackets, 12 percent, 25 percent, and 35 percent --

MURPHY: I mean, small businesses is like --

BARTIROMO: Doubling the standard deduction.

MURPHY: Yes. I'd like to point out, those aren't republican small businesses, those are democrat, republican, American small businesses. So that impacts everybody not just one side. This isn't a one side versus the other.

BARTIROMO: Right. And the reason that I have to push back on that Chris is because we were expecting the talking points after this plan and it's just not true that 80 percent of the tax plan impacts the top one percent, it's just not true and we have to make it clear.

LIU: You know, the problem is, we don't have the details yet.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Everyone should stand, not must stand. While Goodell said he just wants to keep the politics out of football. President Trump, responded on Twitter, "NFL, too much talk, not enough action. Stand for the national anthem." And while Colin Kaepernick, the first anthem kneeler, remained silent except for retweets about not enough attention being given to what he says police brutality against people of color. The Seahawks' Michael Bennett isn't interested in discussing how to fix these social issues. While the NFL team owners are trying to.

Why? He says, "I don't think we can work alongside them until we address that issue. I think the issue with Kaepernick is the start to a conversation. If they want us to be open to what they want, the dialogue, then that's something that needs to be on the table right there." So, Kaepernick first and then the issues.

Some kneel, some protests, some put their money where their mouth is, like the Philadelphia Eagles' Chris Long who has supported teammates protesting the national anthem but is also doing something else. Chris Long of the Eagles, who had donated his first six-game paychecks this season to fund two scholarships at a prep school in Charlottesville where he grew up is now donating the rest of his 2017 NFL salary. Ten more paychecks to help fund education to make it for folks who are -- don't get the opportunities in certain cities -- ten weeks of paychecks going to this in cities of St. Louis, Boston and also Philadelphia.

BARTIROMO: That is great.

KELLY: Leading by example.

GABRIELLE: Football has a 10 for Tomorrow campaign. Good on him for that.

BARTIROMO: Hey, go Yanks!

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Sorry, Max.

(LAUGHTER)

MURPHY: Yes, this should be the go Yanks.

MAX: Some Mets fans started this as soon when the Yankees beat the Mets, and he got Wednesday missing. Somehow, the Yankees do this.

BARTIROMO: Well, Mets are still amazing. Sorry. All right. Jared Max. Catch Jared's sports reports on "FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7," SiriusXM 115. I want to bring you this breaking news: the president is tweeting this morning. Here is what he said, "Republicans are going for big budget approval today. The first step toward massive tax cuts. I think we have the votes, but who knows?" Uh-oh!

(LAUGHTER)

KELLY: Who knows? Caveat.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I guess they need the caveat in this day and age. We'll take a break. When we come back, cities are mailing in their bid to Amazon. We're taking a look at the other crazy stumps from towns competing for technology giants' second headquarters, wait until you see this. That's next hour in MORNINGS WITH MARIA, right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back! Good Thursday morning, everybody. Happy Thursday to you. Thanks for being with us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, October 19th. Your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast. A market milestone yesterday. Yes, the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing above 23,000 for the first time ever. This was the 51st record close since President Trump took office. Earnings and IBM driving the game yesterday.
