urn:contentItem:5VKT-36X1-DY0W-44PT-00000-00Market Milestone; Futures Under Pressure; ISIS PLots New Attack; Dangerous Fly-by; Goodell's Soft Stance; GE Eyes Cost Cuts; DOW CLoses2017-10-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:40ZLexisNexisMarket Milestone; Futures Under Pressure; ISIS PLots New Attack; Dangerous Fly-by; Goodell's Soft Stance; GE Eyes Cost Cuts; DOW CLosesLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good morning ladies, how are you? Thank you so much and good morning everybody. Happy Thursday to you. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, October 19th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Thirty years ago a market milestone and yesterday, a major market milestone as well.

(VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The DOW Jones Industrial Average closing above 23,000 for the first time ever yesterday. It was the f1st record close since President Trump took office. An amazing momentum market.

Earnings driving the gains yesterday, the optimism over tax cuts has underpinned market gains for months as well and we could be one step closer to it today. The Senate gears up for the budget vote later today. President Trump is calling this a once in a lifetime opportunity.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It will be the largest tax cut in the history of our country. I focus on tax cuts because it's such an important weapon to get our country really moving.

So we'll go from being one of the highest tax nations in the world to one of the lowest tax. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity in my opinion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We've got all of the updates coming up. Geopolitical tensions this morning however weighing on markets. Pulling things back from yesterday's all time high.

DOW Industrial expected to be down about 80 points at the opening of trading, down about a third of a percent, Nasdaq down two-thirds of a percent right now.

In Europe this morning, take a look at the action, all the major averages down as you see there with the FTSE100 down a quarter of a percent, the CAC Krones down almost half of a percent and the DAX Index down better than one half of one percent.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly lower with the exception of Japan which was up again taking a cue from the U.S., up half of a percent.

A brand new terrorism threat to report, the Department of Homeland Security is warning that ISIS is plotting another 9/11 style attack, details on this terrifying plan aiming to inflict mass casualties. We've got all the details.

And a scary scene at the German airport, an Air Berlin Jet does a dangerous fly-by with 200 passengers on board, the fallout from the active defiance coming up.

NFL Commission Roger Goodell refusing to take a tougher stance on anthem protests and nobody is happy with Goodell's comments even Colin Kaepernick, he fired back without opening his mouth. We'll tell you what he said.

General Electric eyes major cost cuts, "The Wall Street Journal" this morning reporting some of the excessive spending at the company including Former CEO Jeff Immelt flying an empty jet next to his jet as a back up during his 16-year tenure. Wow.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle is here. Kelly and Company Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly is here. And Rosecliff Capital CEO, Mike Murphy is here. Great to see you.

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER: Good morning. Great to be here.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Happy Thursday everybody.

GABRIELLE: We have 5,000 foot jump since President Trump took office in the DOW but this tax plan, man, I'll tell you, we're going to have to see what happens.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely, 23,000 and counting. I mean, come on.

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: And you know what's fascinating is actually Janet Yellen is due to have a meeting today at the White House with President Trump.

And so whatever happens at the Fed and whoever they pick next is going to have significant impacts on the markets and one of the reasons why you can see that is because the Fed has been so accommodative to this market.

You've seen asset inflation, I mean valuations are at all time highs. So it's a fascinating aspect because Secretary MNuchin has reported that he doesn't like Kevin Warsh because he think he could royal markets, right?

He wasn't for quantitative using, he actually was very adamant against it. And so Jerome Powell is more accommodative.

BARTIROMO: We may know this week or next who the president decides on, we're going to get to all of that coming up.

But first, our top story this hour and that is the market milestone, 23,000. The DOW Industrial closed above the 23,000 mark for the first time ever yesterday. Treasury Secretary Steven MNuchin though made an important comment throughout the day warning that all of those games could be in jeopardy should Congress fail to pass tax reform.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY TEXT:

There is no question that the rally in the stock market has based into it reasonably high expectations of us getting tax cuts and tax reform done. It also has based into it optimism on regulatory relief which they begun to see and there's expectations. So I think to the extent we get the tax deal done, the stock market will go up higher but there's no question in my mind if we don't get it done, you're going to see a reversal of the significant amount of these gains.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: sounds about right, the Senate is expected to vote today on a budget that would allow the Chamber to pass a tax bill with just 51 votes instead of the 60 needed for major legislation.

Joining us right now to talk more about that is Former Chief Strategist for Texas Senator Ted Cruz, his senate and president campaign, Jason Johnson is with us along with Former Deputy Secretary of Labor in the Obama Administration, now a Senior Fellow at the University of Virginia Miller Center, Chris Liu. Good to see you both gentlemen, Thank you so much for joining us this morning.

CHRIS LIU, FORMER DEPUTY SECRETARY OF LABOR, OBAMA ADMINISTRATION: Thank you.

JASON JOHNSON, FORMER CRUZ CAMPAIGN CHIEF STRATEGIST: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: So Jason, in that same interview, the Treasury Secretary made those comments about the market, he offered this, an absolutely guarantee that a tax overhaul would be sign into law by the end of this year. Is that a reasonable time table? Do you think they will get this done?

JOHNSON: Well certainly if you look at the performance this year with other major pieces of legislation it doesn't seem reasonable. But I understand why the Secretary is saying what he's saying.

There is an absolute expectation that this has to be done in the political market if you will. And so I'm not incredibly optimistic that it happens by the end of the year. There certainly seems to be a mixed message coming from some leaders on the Hill as to whether or not the deadline is the end of the year. But whether it's the end of the year or after the first of the year, it must happen.

BARTIROMO: Chris, do you agree with that that it must happen and that it will happen?

LIU: I agree with Senator McConnell who said it's more important that we get it right instead of just running this through. And I think it's important to look at the details here and we don't really know yet percentage is going to go to the super wealthy, how it's going to add to the deficit whether it's really going to fix the idiosyncrasies in the tax code right now.

And so putting it on an artificial deadline does not bode well for coming up with good policy and that's really what the market wants to see right now. They really want to see the once in a generation tax reform proposal, not another giveaway that just goes to the super wealthy.

KELLY: Yes, Chris considering -- it's Kevin Kelly here. Considering you spent time in the White House especially with President Obama, do you think it's appropriate for a cabinet secretaries or anybody in this administration to be talking about the impact on stock markets given that they should be focusing on policy and talking about the implements, what it could do to the real economy as opposed to really focusing on markets that should do whatever they should be doing?

LIU: That's exactly right. It's one of the reasons why we in the Obama Administration didn't talk about the stock market even though we had significant gains as well because the market goes up and unfortunately it goes down as well.

And it goes up or down for reasons that have nothing to do with Washington. And if I were Secretary MNuchin, I would probably take my cues from the leaders on the Hill as to what the timing should be.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, I know. I think that's a good point but at the same time, $5.3 trillion in market value doesn't come out of air. It's clear that the market value that we've seen in these gains is partly due to optimism over what President Trump is doing.

He's rolled back an incredible amount of regulation and they're expecting tax reform. Are you saying $5.3 trillion in market value is just a coincidence?

LIU: Well I would say that it's based on the expectation something's happening. This is a recovery, economic recovery that began in early 2010 and we've had essentially seven straight years of economic growth.

There have been rollbacks of regulations but there hasn't been this significant economic change that Donald Trump has promised yet. So a lot of this is --

BARTIROMO: Well, we did see a 3.1 percent GDP the other day and GDP was averaging about one and a half percent under President Obama. So -- I mean there's something to it that the economy is definitely better.

You're (INAUDIBLE) in small business, do you see that Mike Murphy? Do you see things getting better? Yes.

MURPHY: Absolutely. We see small business optimism out there, we see startups, we see companies that are looking to disrupt existing industries coming out hiring people, raising money, going out and creating -- using technology to make our lives better. So I think right now the optimism that we see nationwide is something we haven't seen in a long time.

BARTIROMO: Jason, let me ask you this, in terms of this bill, if it gets done in the first quarter, do you think that still has a positive impact? If we don't see a bill on the president's desk by Thanksgiving, this is going to be a problem for certainly into the 2018 election for the republicans.

JOHNSON: Sure. Going back to the comment earlier that we shouldn't have artificial deadlines. I don't believe getting this done by the end of the year or seeing that we need to get it done by the end of the year is an artificial deadline because we know historically that very few things happen in election year.

And as we all know, next year is an election year. So Maria, into the first quarter, maybe so but we know that you get much passed the first quarter these guys don't like to do much in an election year.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And you're right, if they don't get it done maybe that's -- they should move out because this is something that the American people want, Lea Gabrielle.

GABRIELLE: Yes. Chris, Senator Schumer said our republican friends are trying to hide what's in the tax bill that they don't want people to know.

Is this just resistance sort of popping up already from the democrats on this obstructionist because really tax reform is good for all Americans right now, is it?

LIU: A hundred percent agree tax reform is good. What we have seen so far is simply tax cuts and some of the initial estimates are that becoming 50 to 80 percent of the benefits would go to the top one percent. Look --

BARTIROMO: That's not true. That's just not true. I don't want to spew out nonsense because 80 percent of the tax reform package going to the top one percent is nonsense.

LIU: An important issue to get right. For instance, it's the state and local tax deduction which is going to affect a lot republican members and understanding the details of that is not just resistance, it's actually trying to make sure that this is legitimate tax reform and there are so many issues. This is why this is hard and it's hard to get it right.

BARTIROMO: You're talking about a corporate rate of 20 percent. If you see the corporate rate go down from 35 percent to 20 percent, that will be a positive for corporations and the idea is is that they are going to reinvest in higher (INAUDIBLE)

KELLY: It's small businesses.

BARTIROMO: Small business with 25 percent pass through rate, same thing down from 39.6. So this is a significant move. He's also talking about three brackets, 12 percent, 25 percent, and 35 percent --

MURPHY: I mean, small businesses is like --

BARTIROMO: Doubling the standard deduction.

MURPHY: Yes. I'd like to point out, those aren't republican small businesses, those are democrat, republican, American small businesses. So that impacts everybody not just one side. This isn't a one side versus the other.

BARTIROMO: Right. And the reason that I have to push back on that Chris is because we were expecting the talking points after this plan and it's just not true that 80 percent of the tax plan impacts the top one percent, it's just not true and we have to make it clear.

LIU: You know, the problem is, we don't have the details yet.

BARTIROMO: I'm sorry?

LIU: We don't have the -- we don't have the details yet and I think that's the problem --

BARTIROMO: Well we have the details that we just mentioned, we got three brackets on the individual rates, we got a doubling of the standard deduction, corporate rate of 20 percent, pass through rate of 25 percent, and the elimination of most deductions.

LIU: Well look, we don't really know what the impact is on average Americans, we don't know what the size of the (INAUDIBLE) tax credit is going to be, we don't understand all the other archaic idiosyncrasy that's --

BARTIROMO: So then how can you say it benefits the one percent if you don't even have the details?

LIU: Well -- look, we're -- the folks that have looked at this are basing this on the initial proposal. Let's have a whole debate on this and let's make sure we get this right.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you this because this is -- we're watching President Obama return to the campaign trail Chris to stump for democratic candidates and governance races, of course, in New Jersey and in Virginia, out of next month elections.

This development comes amid a shakeup at the DNC where several key long time officials have lost their post. The party's new chairman, Tom Perez obviously preparing to host his first meeting since taking over the job earlier this year.

You were among the 75 people nominated by Tom Perez to become the new at large DNC member, what's behind the shakeup? Tell us how you're feeling? Congratulations by that nomination by the way Chris.

LIU: Well look, there are about 400 members of the Democratic National Committee. The new chairman get to pick 75. This is a time of change within the Democratic Party and I think we need to admit that things haven't gone as well as they should have over the last couple of years.

And so unfortunately when you bring new people in, some people that have served for a while have to be moved and that's just part of change. And this is a big 10 party and change happens and change is good.

BARTIROMO: You know, one thing that seems to be happening is that the Democratic Party is being hijacked by the extreme left Chris.

Are you going to be able to come up with a message that will resonate with the broad American people, the population given the fact that you've got Barrack Obama, you've got Bernie Sanders, you've got Elizabeth Warren going to the extreme left and really hijacking what was a moderate party at one point?

LIU: Tom Perez has made a commitment that the democrats need to compete in every seat from the school board to the Senate to the White House.

And we need to understand that we as a party can't have one monolithic message. That doesn't work in all state and certainly doesn't even work in all rural areas versus urban areas as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's a good point. All right. Gentlemen, thanks very much for the conversation we appreciate you joining us this morning. Chris Liu. Jason, good to see you as well. We will talk with you soon gentlemen.

Coming up, the head of Homeland Security is warning Americans of a new threat, the concern over ISIS plotting another 9/11 next. We are going to tell you the details of what we know.

Then Colin Kaepernick firing back at NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell, the new way he's lashing out against him straight ahead.

A fired up morning thins morning, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A top U.S. security chief warning terror groups are planning a major attack on the scale of 9/11. Cheryl Casone with the details now, Cheryl --

CASONE: That's right Maria, good morning. Acting Homeland Security Secretary Elaine Duke saying it is clear that ISIS and other terror groups are planning to take down planes as an aim to carry out another massive attack. Duke also saying terror groups have been using knife and van attacks to keep their members engaged.

Well the head of American Express, one of the country's most prominent African-American corporate leaders is leaving the company, Kenneth Chenault depature caps a 16-year run at the credit card company. He's going to be succeeding a CEO by Stephen Squeri a three decade AmEx veteran. Shares of AmEx up 23 percent so far this year.

Well, American cities are pulling all the stops in their bid to become home to Amazon's second headquarters. Stonecrest, Georgia has offered to change its name to Amazon. Tucson, Arizona tried to send a company a 21-foot cactus.

Amazon has promised to invest $5 billion and create up to 50,000 jobs. The deadline to submit bids is today. And, of course, check this out, New York City lit up famous buildings including the Empire State Building and one World Trade in Amazon's orange color last night trying to help seal the deal. Probably going to be a little more than light that's going to get Amazon somewhere.

And then finally there's this, first lady Melania Trump is donating her inaugural ball gown to the Smithsonian National Museum of American History. She is handing over the vanilla silk off the shoulder gown, it's got a slit skirt. The tradition first began Maria with Helen Taft back in 1912.

BARTIROMO: Wow. Cool. Thank you so much Cheryl. Interesting. Would you go see the first lady's gown at the Smithsonian Lea?

GABRIELLE: I think if I was already going to the Smithsonian then I would happen to pass by and see the first lady's gown.

But I do think that this is really nice about making (INAUDIBLE) because it gives you a sense of being able to even that you can't touch them, just being able to sort of look at them and sort of have the essence of what it must have been like to be there that day. So I think it's wonderful that they do this.

KELLY: I think it also highlights the importance of the first lady, right? I mean you go throughout history and you look at the contributions they've made. So it's nice that --

MURPHY: The guy who's getting married in New York.

KELLY: Yes.

MURPHY: I was going to say behind every great man is a better woman.

BARTIROMO: Yes, says the guy who's getting married.

KELLY: Yes. Yes, exactly. So --

BARTIROMO: Let's talk about your upcoming nuptial.

KELLY: Well she did get her dress last Friday so maybe I'm just kind of high upbeat excited.

urn:contentItem:5PS7-Y931-JBHT-D176-00000-00Market Milestone; Futures Under Pressure; ISIS PLots New Attack; Dangerous Fly-by; Goodell's Soft Stance; GE Eyes Cost Cuts; DOW CLoses2017-10-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:40ZLexisNexisMarket Milestone; Futures Under Pressure; ISIS PLots New Attack; Dangerous Fly-by; Goodell's Soft Stance; GE Eyes Cost Cuts; DOW CLosesLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good morning ladies, how are you? Thank you so much and good morning everybody. Happy Thursday to you. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, October 19th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Thirty years ago a market milestone and yesterday, a major market milestone as well.

(VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The DOW Jones Industrial Average closing above 23,000 for the first time ever yesterday. It was the f1st record close since President Trump took office. An amazing momentum market.

Earnings driving the gains yesterday, the optimism over tax cuts has underpinned market gains for months as well and we could be one step closer to it today. The Senate gears up for the budget vote later today. President Trump is calling this a once in a lifetime opportunity.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It will be the largest tax cut in the history of our country. I focus on tax cuts because it's such an important weapon to get our country really moving.

So we'll go from being one of the highest tax nations in the world to one of the lowest tax. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity in my opinion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We've got all of the updates coming up. Geopolitical tensions this morning however weighing on markets. Pulling things back from yesterday's all time high.

DOW Industrial expected to be down about 80 points at the opening of trading, down about a third of a percent, Nasdaq down two-thirds of a percent right now.

In Europe this morning, take a look at the action, all the major averages down as you see there with the FTSE100 down a quarter of a percent, the CAC Krones down almost half of a percent and the DAX Index down better than one half of one percent.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly lower with the exception of Japan which was up again taking a cue from the U.S., up half of a percent.

A brand new terrorism threat to report, the Department of Homeland Security is warning that ISIS is plotting another 9/11 style attack, details on this terrifying plan aiming to inflict mass casualties. We've got all the details.

And a scary scene at the German airport, an Air Berlin Jet does a dangerous fly-by with 200 passengers on board, the fallout from the active defiance coming up.

NFL Commission Roger Goodell refusing to take a tougher stance on anthem protests and nobody is happy with Goodell's comments even Colin Kaepernick, he fired back without opening his mouth. We'll tell you what he said.

General Electric eyes major cost cuts, "The Wall Street Journal" this morning reporting some of the excessive spending at the company including Former CEO Jeff Immelt flying an empty jet next to his jet as a back up during his 16-year tenure. Wow.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle is here. Kelly and Company Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly is here. And Rosecliff Capital CEO, Mike Murphy is here. Great to see you.

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER: Good morning. Great to be here.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Happy Thursday everybody.

GABRIELLE: We have 5,000 foot jump since President Trump took office in the DOW but this tax plan, man, I'll tell you, we're going to have to see what happens.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely, 23,000 and counting. I mean, come on.

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: And you know what's fascinating is actually Janet Yellen is due to have a meeting today at the White House with President Trump.

And so whatever happens at the Fed and whoever they pick next is going to have significant impacts on the markets and one of the reasons why you can see that is because the Fed has been so accommodative to this market.

You've seen asset inflation, I mean valuations are at all time highs. So it's a fascinating aspect because Secretary MNuchin has reported that he doesn't like Kevin Warsh because he think he could royal markets, right?

He wasn't for quantitative using, he actually was very adamant against it. And so Jerome Powell is more accommodative.

BARTIROMO: We may know this week or next who the president decides on, we're going to get to all of that coming up.

But first, our top story this hour and that is the market milestone, 23,000. The DOW Industrial closed above the 23,000 mark for the first time ever yesterday. Treasury Secretary Steven MNuchin though made an important comment throughout the day warning that all of those games could be in jeopardy should Congress fail to pass tax reform.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY TEXT:

There is no question that the rally in the stock market has based into it reasonably high expectations of us getting tax cuts and tax reform done. It also has based into it optimism on regulatory relief which they begun to see and there's expectations. So I think to the extent we get the tax deal done, the stock market will go up higher but there's no question in my mind if we don't get it done, you're going to see a reversal of the significant amount of these gains.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: sounds about right, the Senate is expected to vote today on a budget that would allow the Chamber to pass a tax bill with just 51 votes instead of the 60 needed for major legislation.

Joining us right now to talk more about that is Former Chief Strategist for Texas Senator Ted Cruz, his senate and president campaign, Jason Johnson is with us along with Former Deputy Secretary of Labor in the Obama Administration, now a Senior Fellow at the University of Virginia Miller Center, Chris Liu. Good to see you both gentlemen, Thank you so much for joining us this morning.

CHRIS LIU, FORMER DEPUTY SECRETARY OF LABOR, OBAMA ADMINISTRATION: Thank you.

JASON JOHNSON, FORMER CRUZ CAMPAIGN CHIEF STRATEGIST: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: So Jason, in that same interview, the Treasury Secretary made those comments about the market, he offered this, an absolutely guarantee that a tax overhaul would be sign into law by the end of this year. Is that a reasonable time table? Do you think they will get this done?

JOHNSON: Well certainly if you look at the performance this year with other major pieces of legislation it doesn't seem reasonable. But I understand why the Secretary is saying what he's saying.

There is an absolute expectation that this has to be done in the political market if you will. And so I'm not incredibly optimistic that it happens by the end of the year. There certainly seems to be a mixed message coming from some leaders on the Hill as to whether or not the deadline is the end of the year. But whether it's the end of the year or after the first of the year, it must happen.

BARTIROMO: Chris, do you agree with that that it must happen and that it will happen?

LIU: I agree with Senator McConnell who said it's more important that we get it right instead of just running this through. And I think it's important to look at the details here and we don't really know yet percentage is going to go to the super wealthy, how it's going to add to the deficit whether it's really going to fix the idiosyncrasies in the tax code right now.

And so putting it on an artificial deadline does not bode well for coming up with good policy and that's really what the market wants to see right now. They really want to see the once in a generation tax reform proposal, not another giveaway that just goes to the super wealthy.

KELLY: Yes, Chris considering -- it's Kevin Kelly here. Considering you spent time in the White House especially with President Obama, do you think it's appropriate for a cabinet secretaries or anybody in this administration to be talking about the impact on stock markets given that they should be focusing on policy and talking about the implements, what it could do to the real economy as opposed to really focusing on markets that should do whatever they should be doing?

LIU: That's exactly right. It's one of the reasons why we in the Obama Administration didn't talk about the stock market even though we had significant gains as well because the market goes up and unfortunately it goes down as well.

And it goes up or down for reasons that have nothing to do with Washington. And if I were Secretary MNuchin, I would probably take my cues from the leaders on the Hill as to what the timing should be.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, I know. I think that's a good point but at the same time, $5.3 trillion in market value doesn't come out of air. It's clear that the market value that we've seen in these gains is partly due to optimism over what President Trump is doing.

He's rolled back an incredible amount of regulation and they're expecting tax reform. Are you saying $5.3 trillion in market value is just a coincidence?

LIU: Well I would say that it's based on the expectation something's happening. This is a recovery, economic recovery that began in early 2010 and we've had essentially seven straight years of economic growth.

There have been rollbacks of regulations but there hasn't been this significant economic change that Donald Trump has promised yet. So a lot of this is --

BARTIROMO: Well, we did see a 3.1 percent GDP the other day and GDP was averaging about one and a half percent under President Obama. So -- I mean there's something to it that the economy is definitely better.

You're (INAUDIBLE) in small business, do you see that Mike Murphy? Do you see things getting better? Yes.

MURPHY: Absolutely. We see small business optimism out there, we see startups, we see companies that are looking to disrupt existing industries coming out hiring people, raising money, going out and creating -- using technology to make our lives better. So I think right now the optimism that we see nationwide is something we haven't seen in a long time.

BARTIROMO: Jason, let me ask you this, in terms of this bill, if it gets done in the first quarter, do you think that still has a positive impact? If we don't see a bill on the president's desk by Thanksgiving, this is going to be a problem for certainly into the 2018 election for the republicans.

JOHNSON: Sure. Going back to the comment earlier that we shouldn't have artificial deadlines. I don't believe getting this done by the end of the year or seeing that we need to get it done by the end of the year is an artificial deadline because we know historically that very few things happen in election year.

And as we all know, next year is an election year. So Maria, into the first quarter, maybe so but we know that you get much passed the first quarter these guys don't like to do much in an election year.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And you're right, if they don't get it done maybe that's -- they should move out because this is something that the American people want, Lea Gabrielle.

GABRIELLE: Yes. Chris, Senator Schumer said our republican friends are trying to hide what's in the tax bill that they don't want people to know.

Is this just resistance sort of popping up already from the democrats on this obstructionist because really tax reform is good for all Americans right now, is it?

LIU: A hundred percent agree tax reform is good. What we have seen so far is simply tax cuts and some of the initial estimates are that becoming 50 to 80 percent of the benefits would go to the top one percent. Look --

BARTIROMO: That's not true. That's just not true. I don't want to spew out nonsense because 80 percent of the tax reform package going to the top one percent is nonsense.

LIU: An important issue to get right. For instance, it's the state and local tax deduction which is going to affect a lot republican members and understanding the details of that is not just resistance, it's actually trying to make sure that this is legitimate tax reform and there are so many issues. This is why this is hard and it's hard to get it right.

BARTIROMO: You're talking about a corporate rate of 20 percent. If you see the corporate rate go down from 35 percent to 20 percent, that will be a positive for corporations and the idea is is that they are going to reinvest in higher (INAUDIBLE)

KELLY: It's small businesses.

BARTIROMO: Small business with 25 percent pass through rate, same thing down from 39.6. So this is a significant move. He's also talking about three brackets, 12 percent, 25 percent, and 35 percent --

MURPHY: I mean, small businesses is like --

BARTIROMO: Doubling the standard deduction.

MURPHY: Yes. I'd like to point out, those aren't republican small businesses, those are democrat, republican, American small businesses. So that impacts everybody not just one side. This isn't a one side versus the other.

BARTIROMO: Right. And the reason that I have to push back on that Chris is because we were expecting the talking points after this plan and it's just not true that 80 percent of the tax plan impacts the top one percent, it's just not true and we have to make it clear.

LIU: You know, the problem is, we don't have the details yet.

BARTIROMO: I'm sorry?

LIU: We don't have the -- we don't have the details yet and I think that's the problem --

BARTIROMO: Well we have the details that we just mentioned, we got three brackets on the individual rates, we got a doubling of the standard deduction, corporate rate of 20 percent, pass through rate of 25 percent, and the elimination of most deductions.

LIU: Well look, we don't really know what the impact is on average Americans, we don't know what the size of the (INAUDIBLE) tax credit is going to be, we don't understand all the other archaic idiosyncrasy that's --

BARTIROMO: So then how can you say it benefits the one percent if you don't even have the details?

LIU: Well -- look, we're -- the folks that have looked at this are basing this on the initial proposal. Let's have a whole debate on this and let's make sure we get this right.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you this because this is -- we're watching President Obama return to the campaign trail Chris to stump for democratic candidates and governance races, of course, in New Jersey and in Virginia, out of next month elections.

This development comes amid a shakeup at the DNC where several key long time officials have lost their post. The party's new chairman, Tom Perez obviously preparing to host his first meeting since taking over the job earlier this year.

You were among the 75 people nominated by Tom Perez to become the new at large DNC member, what's behind the shakeup? Tell us how you're feeling? Congratulations by that nomination by the way Chris.

LIU: Well look, there are about 400 members of the Democratic National Committee. The new chairman get to pick 75. This is a time of change within the Democratic Party and I think we need to admit that things haven't gone as well as they should have over the last couple of years.

And so unfortunately when you bring new people in, some people that have served for a while have to be moved and that's just part of change. And this is a big 10 party and change happens and change is good.

BARTIROMO: You know, one thing that seems to be happening is that the Democratic Party is being hijacked by the extreme left Chris.

Are you going to be able to come up with a message that will resonate with the broad American people, the population given the fact that you've got Barrack Obama, you've got Bernie Sanders, you've got Elizabeth Warren going to the extreme left and really hijacking what was a moderate party at one point?

LIU: Tom Perez has made a commitment that the democrats need to compete in every seat from the school board to the Senate to the White House.

And we need to understand that we as a party can't have one monolithic message. That doesn't work in all state and certainly doesn't even work in all rural areas versus urban areas as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's a good point. All right. Gentlemen, thanks very much for the conversation we appreciate you joining us this morning. Chris Liu. Jason, good to see you as well. We will talk with you soon gentlemen.

Coming up, the head of Homeland Security is warning Americans of a new threat, the concern over ISIS plotting another 9/11 next. We are going to tell you the details of what we know.

Then Colin Kaepernick firing back at NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell, the new way he's lashing out against him straight ahead.

A fired up morning thins morning, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A top U.S. security chief warning terror groups are planning a major attack on the scale of 9/11. Cheryl Casone with the details now, Cheryl --

CASONE: That's right Maria, good morning. Acting Homeland Security Secretary Elaine Duke saying it is clear that ISIS and other terror groups are planning to take down planes as an aim to carry out another massive attack. Duke also saying terror groups have been using knife and van attacks to keep their members engaged.

Well the head of American Express, one of the country's most prominent African-American corporate leaders is leaving the company, Kenneth Chenault depature caps a 16-year run at the credit card company. He's going to be succeeding a CEO by Stephen Squeri a three decade AmEx veteran. Shares of AmEx up 23 percent so far this year.

Well, American cities are pulling all the stops in their bid to become home to Amazon's second headquarters. Stonecrest, Georgia has offered to change its name to Amazon. Tucson, Arizona tried to send a company a 21-foot cactus.

Amazon has promised to invest $5 billion and create up to 50,000 jobs. The deadline to submit bids is today. And, of course, check this out, New York City lit up famous buildings including the Empire State Building and one World Trade in Amazon's orange color last night trying to help seal the deal. Probably going to be a little more than light that's going to get Amazon somewhere.

And then finally there's this, first lady Melania Trump is donating her inaugural ball gown to the Smithsonian National Museum of American History. She is handing over the vanilla silk off the shoulder gown, it's got a slit skirt. The tradition first began Maria with Helen Taft back in 1912.

BARTIROMO: Wow. Cool. Thank you so much Cheryl. Interesting. Would you go see the first lady's gown at the Smithsonian Lea?

GABRIELLE: I think if I was already going to the Smithsonian then I would happen to pass by and see the first lady's gown.

But I do think that this is really nice about making (INAUDIBLE) because it gives you a sense of being able to even that you can't touch them, just being able to sort of look at them and sort of have the essence of what it must have been like to be there that day. So I think it's wonderful that they do this.

KELLY: I think it also highlights the importance of the first lady, right? I mean you go throughout history and you look at the contributions they've made. So it's nice that --

MURPHY: The guy who's getting married in New York.

KELLY: Yes.

MURPHY: I was going to say behind every great man is a better woman.

BARTIROMO: Yes, says the guy who's getting married.

KELLY: Yes. Yes, exactly. So --

BARTIROMO: Let's talk about your upcoming nuptial.

KELLY: Well she did get her dress last Friday so maybe I'm just kind of high upbeat excited.

BARTIROMO: Oh, she got the dress.

KELLY: Yes, I know. So obviously I didn't see it but it was a fun and exciting experience.

GABRIELLE: I was going to say, let's see a live TV picture of this and get you in really big trouble.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll keep following all of that. Coming up next though, a real scare in the sky to tell you about, more video of the risky fly-by stunt that got pilot suspended, that's coming up.

And then GE's new chief taking away company cars and cancelling fancy retreats. The new cost cutting direction for General Electric ahead of its earnings tomorrow, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. General Electric's new CEO John Flannery making some changes starting with some old favorites. Tracee Carrasco with the details, Tracee --

TRACEE CARRASCO, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning Maria. You know, John Flannery, he's only been on the job since August 1st but he's already making some big changes.

One of his first belt tightening moves was to ground GE's fleet of six business jets which was a favorite of former GE CEO Jeff Immelt who used to have an empty private jet fly next to his just as a spare and that's just the beginning.

Bob Nardelli, former Chrysler CEO and Home CEO was on the show yesterday and here's what he had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BOB NARDELLI, FORMER CEO HOME DEPOT & CHRYSLER: They have to get their fundamental businesses that are left to get some growth. They got to get growth, they've got to get top line growth, they got to get productivity, they got to get innovation.

The key to GE over the last 16 years Maria as we've seen that goes out have been a lot more than the goes in.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARRASCO: And Nardelli worked at GE for several years. And according to "The Wall Street Journal," next month Flannery is expected to unveil the results of a strategic review that includes thousands of corporate level job cuts and scaling back of GE's global structure.

He is shutting down research centers in Shanghai, Munich, and Rio democrats Janiero. A GE spokesperson said:

TEXT: The company will continue to have an intense focus on our global operations and customer base.

The company is expected to report quarterly reports tomorrow.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Look at that stock ahead of those --

CARRASCO: Hasn't been good.

BARTIROMO: Ahead of those numbers. The stock has been cut in half from the highs. No, wait a minute. Let's just underline what you just said Tracee, he had a separate jet flying behind his jet on business trips and the jet flying behind him was empty.

CARRASCO: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And he did that for what reason?

CARRASCO: Just in case there were any issues with the private jet he was already on.

KELLY: Yes. I mean --

GABRIELLE: I flew in the navy and I have a commanding officer who made me take a jet to an air show because it was his hometown and he wanted to make sure that if his jet, if there's anything wrong with it he couldn't fly in the air show but there was a spare there. So I've seen this before, pretty wasteful.

KELLY: Yes. But the biggest problem is they have shareholders, right, that they're held accountable too and I'm sorry --

BARTIROMO: It's a public company.

KELLY: Listen, you don't need to fly a private jet next to you. Listen, if your plane has mechanical issues, guess what, then we'll figure out and we'll rent a private jet that's there to take you back to wherever you need to go. You don't -- yes, exactly.

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: Well here's the problem, the board. If I was a member on the board, how can you -- you've got to be held accountable. I mean, they -- like coming out of GE tomorrow and whether they cut the dividend, that's one of the biggest concerns that shareholders are having right now.

BARTIROMO: Yes, sure is.

KELLY: But also what is this board doing if they're allowing this, right? Shareholder capital --

MURPHY: And (INAUDIBLE) I think for an old company like GE that's trying to figure out how to stay relevant in this new economy, I think something like this coming out makes it really hard for shareholders to believe in this.

And you could see people wanting to sell this and look at company if they are really on the cutting edge of technology.

BARTIROMO: And that are growing.

MURPHY: Yes.

GABRIELLE: But they are looking for places to trim the fat just like Tracee mentioned, shutting down some of those research centers and sort of trying to consolidate their resources. So at least we're moving forward in that way.

BARTIROMO: They've got to. We'll see what the company says tomorrow. GE reports at around 8:30a.m. in the morning, tomorrow morning on its third quarter. And, of course, a speculation is around that dividend. Tracee Carrasco, thank you.

We will take a break. When we come back, months after going public, Blue Apron is laying off hundreds of employees. The plan for a company-wide realignment straight ahead.

Then Fortune is revealing their new future 50 list of U.S. companies with the highest potential for growth. We've got the exclusive first look, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. Happy Thursday. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, October 19th. Your top stories right now 6:30a.m. on the East Coast.

The rally is momentous but the market is pulling back from record highs yesterday. The market expected to open down about 100 points after yesterday's huge day. The DOW Jones Industrial Average hitting the 23,000 level for the first time ever.

Markets retreating this morning on some geopolitical tensions. As you can see, futures indicating a decline of 100 points and the Nasdaq down about 36 points. This, of course, the anniversary of Black Monday 30 years ago.

In Europe this morning and Asia, mixed performances. Asian markets look like this, mostly lower this morning. Hang Seng Index down about two percent.

And in Europe this morning, as you see weakness there as well, the FTSE100, the CAC Krones, and the DAX Index down between the third of a percent and two-thirds of a percent. Catalonia in crisis this morning, Spain is moving to take over the region before it can declare independence, why some fear that the decision will spur unrest like never before.

A farewell fly by in Air Berlin, pilot lands in hot water over his low flying stunt to say goodbye to the Airline with 200 passengers aboard, the fallout from the terrifying maneuver, coming up. And Blue Apron is feeling the heat from Amazon. The cooking company announcing hundreds of layoffs just months after going public, what the move means for the meal kit industry as a whole.

Not standing up for the National Anthem, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell under fire this morning from both sides, for not taking a stronger stance on the league's controversial protest. How Colin Kaepernick voiced his complaints with Goodell, without saying a word. And then company comeback Chicago avoids the sweep in an epic game for against the Dodgers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COMMENTATOR: Two and one the count. Balancer hits it hard. Get a chance to turn it, four, six, three and a double play. And the ball game is over. The Cubs win.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The highlights from the late-night thriller at Wrigley Field last night. The Yankees take the lead in the AL Championship Series now. We've got more, coming up on that. But first, a new approach to measuring success, Fortune Magazine is shining a light on the top names driving the business world tomorrow, where is the growth? We want to know. Fortune is debuting its future 50 list today, covering the most innovative companies prime for explosive growth. Fox Business has the exclusive first look at the list.

Coming in at number five on Fortunes' Future 50 Leaders, medical robotics leader, Intuitive Surgical, fourth is the king of the stream, Netflix. Number three on this list, Mark Zuckerberg's dorm project turns social media titan, Facebook. Elon Musk, electric automaker Tesla, cruising into the second spot. And topping the list is cloud computing giant, Salesforce, joining us right now in a Fox Business Exclusive, Working Deputy Editor, Brian O'Keefe. Brian, good to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

BRIAN O'KEEFE, DEPUTY EDITOR OF FORTUNE: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Well, a lot of those names, obviously, very familiar and growth stories that we all know, how did you come up with this list, what are the growth metrics that you used?

O'KEEFE: So we worked with Boston Consulting Group (BCG), they were our partners in doing this. They did an incredible amount of number crunching, and they looked at 15 years of financial data and they scream for all 2,300 U.S. public companies. And they really looked at a couple of things. One is the market potential of all these companies, what the market is betting, how much growth the market is betting and assigning their value.

And then they also dove into the company's themselves and looked at people, structure, their technology and investments, they used artificial intelligence, natural language processing to look at 70,000 10Ks and look at the way those companies talked about themselves, if they talked about future and investment and long-term thinking. And they did a lot of backtesting and looked at what correlated with real growth over time.

BARTIROMO: And it's interesting that Salesforce is the number one -- in the number one spot. Were you surprised with that, Mike?

MURPHY: I was, for sure, because, you know, when you think about growth, you hear the fangs. You know, you hear about Facebook, which is there but Amazon, Netflix, which is there, Google. So, the way this is -- I think this is going to create a lot of controversy from people who are saying, you know, like, oh, here's the big apple, we don't see therearound.

KELLY: Apple didn't make the list, actually.

BARTIROMO: Apple didn't make the list.

KELLY: Apple did not make the list, in part to its recent increase emphasis on paying dividends on over reinvestment.

O'KEEFE: Yes, I mean, you're seeing -- I mean, Apple is the big exception, right? That's, you know, we noted that. And, you know, Apple is obviously still an incredible performer but they are piling up cash, they are paying out dividends under some pressure to shareholders and that's not really a formula for future growth.

You know, you want to see a company, not that Apple is not doing well, but you want to see them putting it in to new technology, Salesforce, to your point, you know, they are -- Marc Benioff keeps that company really focused on the future, they're investing in artificial intelligence and they're making acquisitions on --

KELLY: And I think the important thing about Salesforce, if you look it as -- it didn't surprise me one bit about this, because he's actually struck deals and partnerships with other companies like IBM to have a stronger, better, platform for his customers, right? So for insurance companies, if there's a hail storm, they're going to use IBMs (INAUDIBLE) to notify all the policyholders, so he's done a very good job especially on the acquisition side. So if they had a hole on their business model, he went out and bought them.

GABRIELLE: To look at the list overall, though, you know, a lot of people say the past performance is the best indication of future success and that's really not the way that you created this list, right?

O'KEEFE: Yes, I mean, that's really, kind of, the whole reason we did create this list, is that past performance isn't the indicator of future success and today's environment, things are changing so much faster, technologies speeding up the pace of change, that we felt like in BCG, felt like, we need a better metric to do that. So that, you know, most of the time, you're measuring a company on.

You're trying to project the future on what they've been doing recently. And this is like really -- that's why it's diving into, sort of, the DNA of these companies and how they operate and how they talk and how they think and trying to do that in a scientific way. And, you know, looking at the structure of the company, I mean, the hard reality is that younger companies tend to grow faster, I mean, not just smaller companies, but tightly-managed younger companies.

BARTIROMO: And founder companies, right?

O'KEEFE: And founder companies, a lot of the time, yes.

BARTIROMO: You also put his list of Future 50 Challengers. We just showed it on the screen. These are companies that are on the fast-track for growth but aren't quite there yet. So how did you come up with this list?

O'KEEFE: Well, the secret about the Future 50 is (INAUDIBLE) list of 25. So we have the 25 big companies and the 25 challengers, is what we called it, BCG, didn't want to -- if you're screening for growth, you're going to naturally get smaller companies, so that's why we did two separate screens to get the big companies that are still growing. The challengers are really the companies that are on the rise, not necessarily small companies, but, you know, it can be like, $5 to 10-billion market cap companies. And you see a lot of software companies on the list overall but especially on the challenger's list, I mean, it's really like software is eating the world.

BARTIROMO: That's what Marc Andreessen said years ago, you know, software eats the world.

O'KEEFE: Yes, it's still true. It's true, maybe more than ever. I mean, it's, you know, like Veeva Systems, the number one company in the challenger's list.

BARTIROMO: And Workday has been taking market share from, like, the oracles of the world for years.

O'KEEFE: Workday is huge. I mean, obviously, it's a huge stock, market cap has shut up. And yes, so these are companies that they're displacing traditional systems and they're doing it with software technology.

KELLY: So on Workday, it's a perineal emanate target, right? And I just wanted to highlight the point you said, though, earlier, 64 percent of the companies in this list are software or online service providers.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

GABRIELLE: Yes.

KELLY: That highlights that this is the wave and this is the future of where we are going.

BARTIROMO: You want to find growth, that's where it is.

KELLY: Yes, and a bit in every industry.

GABRIELLE: And one of the things that you have said is that, a lot of companies that are using artificial intelligence are, sort of, higher on the list, but you also used artificial intelligence in developing this list, right?

O'KEEFE: Yes, I mean, that was one of the really cool things that BCG did, is use this natural language processing to troll through 70,000 10Ks = like 200,000 different earnings calls, transcripts, and really look at the language that the management uses to talk about how they managed their own business. And so, and, you know, I don't -- I don't personally know the details of how the artificial intelligence did it, but it correlates certain words and the way they come together with performance.

MURPHY: So, how far down did you guys dig? Like, how low did you go? Because a company like Salesforces which is number one, they have a venture, we ran a venture capital funds.

O'KEEFE: Right.

MURPHY: So Salesforce is actively out there looking to acquire early-stage start-ups. Is there another 50 list of, kind of, the 50 (INAUDIBLE) that's going start-ups or early stage companies?

O'KEEFE: Maybe we will expand that out. But one thing the BCG did do, was look at the investments that company's making, compared to high performing DC funds to, sort of, get a sense of like how good their investments are. So, that's an interesting way.

BARTIROMO: You're hitting on something so important right now. I'm so glad you brought it up, Mike, because you're right, Salesforce has an arm that invests and acquires smaller companies. That's why a lot of these companies as Amazon, you know, other big technology --

KELLY: Intel.

BARTIROMO: Intel, you're seeing large tech right now, have venture capital arm and they are acquiring some of the smaller, no-names out there.

O'KEEFE: You know, we have a story on Salesforce that goes deeper into what they're doing. They bought 55 companies since 2006.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

O'KEEFE: And Marc Benioff, you know, a lot of times, like, maybe he doesn't even exactly know what they're going to do with the company but he knows there's an interesting technology and they make it an acquisition, they figure out how it's going to impact their business.

KELLY: Is there a super surprised company, for you, because I'm looking at this list and I'm not surprised by it, but I think people could be as the intercontinental exchange that, you know, they run the New York stock exchange, but really, those companies, the exchange have been focusing on data, licensing, it's not really --

BARTIROMO: A lot of (INAUDIBLE) mergers.

KELLY: Exactly. So, is there a company on this list that surprised you the most?

O'KEEFE: Surprised me the most, I mean, I'm a little surprised -- Monster Beverage is a really interesting company.

KELLY: Number 20 on that list.

O'KEEFE: Because they have been growing fast for 20 years, and, you know, I don't drink Monster Beverage drinks, but a lot of people do. They're really smart about how they market their brand, they don't really do a lot of advertising but they do a lot of really cool, sort of, sponsorship stuff. And they just, you know, they keep growing that company year after year.

KELLY: And the next leg of growth for Monster Beverage is over in China and Asia, so that's where they're looking to go so if you follow the stock close, you can see they've dominated North America and they've slowly been making inroads and smart positioning in Asia.

BARTIROMO: Look at that chart.

O'KEEFE: You know we have MasterCard and Visa on the list. And I think that's really interesting because they seemed like, you know, it's the card in your wallet. But they're really doing a lot of innovative things. They are trying to be, you know, the future of payments in all different forms.

MURPHY: And when we talk about big tech companies or fin-tech companies doing acquisitions, early-stage investing. But there's also companies like Campbell Soup has (INAUDIBLE) so it's not just big tech that's looking to acquire small innovative companies. I think it's across all diferent --

BARTIROMO: Campbell Soup, wow. And these guys are computer guys like you. We had Ann Winblad on from Winblad, who is a great venture capitalist. And she said, I'm competing with the arms of the soft, you know, of the SoftBanks, not SoftBanks, of the --

MURPHY: The large corporations.

BARTIROMO: The large corporation. The largest technology --

KELLY: Imagine if the repatriation happens, of the taxes of all those trillions of dollars overseas to these companies that they can then re- invest since small businesses start up, things that are happening. I mean, not to tie this into the whole tax reform overhaul policy but that could be a good next leg of growth for this company.

O'KEEFE: First, they have to find the right things to invest in.

KELLY: Yes, of course.

BARTIROMO: These lists are helpful. Brian, thank you so much, Brian O'Keefe joining us. We wanted to also -- should we take a look at IBM real quick. I mean, IBM was obviously stalled in terms of its revenue growth for 22 quarters. You saw a decline in revenue but yesterday, check out that stock yesterday. Nine percent, one of the reasons the Dow Industrials hit 23,000. I just wanted to mention that, is this a turning point for IBM?

MURPHY: I don't think so. I think when you see that type of move, so much of the volume in the markets right now is computer driven or algorithmic trading. That, to me, smells like a short covering -- short squeeze.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll keep watching IBM. Obviously, IBM, GE, two- story stocks that we want to look at today. Brian, good to see you, thank you. Coming up next, the fight is growing over Catalonia's push for independence. How the Spanish government is trying to stop the region's succession, that's next. And then a terrifying close call, more video of that scary fly by that put 200 passengers at risk. We'll tell you all about it, back in a moment, straight ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back! Markets are down this morning after a huge day yesterday. Dow Industrials' expected to be down better than 100 points. No surprise. The market crossed 23,000 yesterday for the first time ever in a big rally, and, of course, we're up to better than $5 trillion in market value since the election.

A couple names on the move, Gilead Sciences; the stock right now is up almost three percent in the premarket after winning FDA approval for a new cancer gene therapy -- used to treat lymphoma. The pharmaceutical giant will sell the treatment at $373,000. It's only the second gene therapy to earn approval from the FDA on that. Novartis brought the first drug of this class to market back in August.

EBay shares this morning on the move after delivering third-quarter earnings after the bell last night. The results were roughly in line but fourth-quarter guidance's disappointed. EBay is revamping its online marketplace amid tough competition from Amazon. Stock, right now, taken a real hit down 6-1/2 percent in the premarket.

And then, there's Spain, the government there is set to activate an emergency measure to take control of Catalonia, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, Maria. So, Spain's government calling a special cabinet for the weekend to activate this measure -- it allows for the central government to take over the semiautonomous power of any of the country's17 regions. Now, this comes after Catalonia's leader said, Separatist lawmakers, can vote in favor of declaration of independence. The measure has never been used in the four decades since democracy was restored in Spain.

Well, an Air Berlin pilot is in big trouble. He performed a risky flying stunt with 200 passengers aboard. You're watching the video of it right now. Reports say he buzzed Dusseldorf Airport terminal in a maneuver that was met to mark the bankrupt last Trans-Atlantic flight. Well, a pilot of another told Reuters that a go-around should only be performed for its operations, or safety aviation officials are looking at this video and looking into this incident.

Well, Blue Apron, they are tightening their belt. The company has laid out six percent of the workforce, that's about 300 workers, as part of a company or organization. Blue Apron has struggled since it went public back in June with its stock price cut in half since then. Competition from a rival, a big one that would-be Amazon. There is the year to date chart, you can see it on your screen.

Meanwhile, Sea World is laying off 350 workers due to low attendance at its parks -- mainly in Orlando and San Diego. They've been trying to rebuild the brand solving protests over its treatment of their killer whales. Shares of Sea World, down more than 34 percent year to date.

And then, finally this, Snickers are getting a facelift, actually three facelifts. The candy company announcing they're going to release a line of three new flavors to combat a number of different, well, emotional issues. Feeling irritable, wimpy, indecisive? Well, they've got the cure. These three bars: espresso, fiery, and salty and sweet, Maria. Right now, I think I want the espresso. I'm a little tired.

BARTIROMO: Wow! Yes, the expresso sounds good.

KELLY: Thanks to wimpy for fiery, right? Like, I like spicy stuff, but it doesn't mean that I'm a wimp.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: He's taking it personally.

GABRIELLE: So -- but personally, I'm really concerned about the espresso one, because if you're irritable, I think the last thing you actually need is to have some more caffeine. More caffeine. I always like those names, though. I actually find that really attractive. When you're in a store and you're looking at candy and you're like, yes, you know, I kind of feel irritable.

BARTIROMO: But do you buy right there? Or will you buy it because of that?

GABRIELLE: No. Only if I really want it.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell, speaking out over the national anthem protest. What he said to players and how they're reacting, next. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Well, it's a big night at Wrigley Field last night. The Cubs fought for their playoff lives and they survived. Jared Max with the highlights, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTS REPORTER: Hey! Good morning, Maria. I know the Dodgers are only one win from the World Series, but just imagine the Cubs came all the way back to win the NLC. Yes, they did what they had to do last night in a do or die game 4.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(BASEBALL GAMEPLAY)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Javier Baez at two home runs; Wilson Contreras also (INAUDIBLE) for the Cubs. Dodgers would blast from Cody Dellinger and Justin Turner, but the Cubs win. Cubs win! Cubs win, 3-2. So, there will be a game 5. Tonight, at Wrigley Field, the Cubs pick Jose Montana. The Dodgers' Clayton Kershaw L.A. leads three games to one.

New York Yankees rookie, Aaron Judge, a hero again last night. A third- inning double off Astros Ace, Dallas Keuchel, gave the Yanks a 2-0 lead. Then, at the seventh inning, fellow baby bomber, Gary Sanchez, smashes a solo home run against Brad Peacock -- third home run this postseason for Sanchez. Yankees' finally got reminisce its Dallas Keuchel and Masahiro Tanaka. 7-shutout innings, 5-0, Yanks win.

Series goes back to Houston where the Astros won the first two games. Here's to start, Justin Verlander tomorrow night, and Yankees turn to Luis Severino. Yanks, one win from their 41st American League pennant.

Hey, you know when somebody says, I'm not asking you, I'm telling you. Well, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell announced the opposite yesterday, regarding players choices to stand or kneel for the national anthem.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROGER GOODELL, COMMISSIONER FOR THE NFL: Everyone should stand for the national anthem, that's an important part of our policy. It's also an important part of our game that we all take great pride in, it's also important for us to honor our flag and to our country, and we think our fans expect us to do that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Everyone should stand, not must stand. While Goodell said he just wants to keep the politics out of football. President Trump, responded on Twitter, "NFL, too much talk, not enough action. Stand for the national anthem." And while Colin Kaepernick, the first anthem kneeler, remained silent except for retweets about not enough attention being given to what he says police brutality against people of color. The Seahawks' Michael Bennett isn't interested in discussing how to fix these social issues. While the NFL team owners are trying to.

Why? He says, "I don't think we can work alongside them until we address that issue. I think the issue with Kaepernick is the start to a conversation. If they want us to be open to what they want, the dialogue, then that's something that needs to be on the table right there." So, Kaepernick first and then the issues.

Some kneel, some protests, some put their money where their mouth is, like the Philadelphia Eagles' Chris Long who has supported teammates protesting the national anthem but is also doing something else. Chris Long of the Eagles, who had donated his first six-game paychecks this season to fund two scholarships at a prep school in Charlottesville where he grew up is now donating the rest of his 2017 NFL salary. Ten more paychecks to help fund education to make it for folks who are -- don't get the opportunities in certain cities -- ten weeks of paychecks going to this in cities of St. Louis, Boston and also Philadelphia.

BARTIROMO: That is great.

KELLY: Leading by example.

GABRIELLE: Football has a 10 for Tomorrow campaign. Good on him for that.

BARTIROMO: Hey, go Yanks!

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Sorry, Max.

(LAUGHTER)

MURPHY: Yes, this should be the go Yanks.

MAX: Some Mets fans started this as soon when the Yankees beat the Mets, and he got Wednesday missing. Somehow, the Yankees do this.

BARTIROMO: Well, Mets are still amazing. Sorry. All right. Jared Max. Catch Jared's sports reports on "FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7," SiriusXM 115. I want to bring you this breaking news: the president is tweeting this morning. Here is what he said, "Republicans are going for big budget approval today. The first step toward massive tax cuts. I think we have the votes, but who knows?" Uh-oh!

(LAUGHTER)

KELLY: Who knows? Caveat.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I guess they need the caveat in this day and age. We'll take a break. When we come back, cities are mailing in their bid to Amazon. We're taking a look at the other crazy stumps from towns competing for technology giants' second headquarters, wait until you see this. That's next hour in MORNINGS WITH MARIA, right here.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back! Good Thursday morning, everybody. Happy Thursday to you. Thanks for being with us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, October 19th. This was the 51st record close since President Trump took office. Earnings and IBM driving the game yesterday.
