BARTIROMO: You also put his list of Future 50 Challengers. We just showed it on the screen. These are companies that are on the fast-track for growth but aren't quite there yet. So how did you come up with this list?

O'KEEFE: Well, the secret about the Future 50 is (INAUDIBLE) list of 25. So we have the 25 big companies and the 25 challengers, is what we called it, BCG, didn't want to -- if you're screening for growth, you're going to naturally get smaller companies, so that's why we did two separate screens to get the big companies that are still growing. The challengers are really the companies that are on the rise, not necessarily small companies, but, you know, it can be like, $5 to 10-billion market cap companies. And you see a lot of software companies on the list overall but especially on the challenger's list, I mean, it's really like software is eating the world.

BARTIROMO: That's what Marc Andreessen said years ago, you know, software eats the world.

O'KEEFE: Yes, it's still true. It's true, maybe more than ever. I mean, it's, you know, like Veeva Systems, the number one company in the challenger's list.

BARTIROMO: And Workday has been taking market share from, like, the oracles of the world for years.

O'KEEFE: Workday is huge. I mean, obviously, it's a huge stock, market cap has shut up. And yes, so these are companies that they're displacing traditional systems and they're doing it with software technology.

KELLY: So on Workday, it's a perineal emanate target, right? And I just wanted to highlight the point you said, though, earlier, 64 percent of the companies in this list are software or online service providers.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

GABRIELLE: Yes.

KELLY: That highlights that this is the wave and this is the future of where we are going.

BARTIROMO: You want to find growth, that's where it is.

KELLY: Yes, and a bit in every industry.

GABRIELLE: And one of the things that you have said is that, a lot of companies that are using artificial intelligence are, sort of, higher on the list, but you also used artificial intelligence in developing this list, right?

O'KEEFE: Yes, I mean, that was one of the really cool things that BCG did, is use this natural language processing to troll through 70,000 10Ks = like 200,000 different earnings calls, transcripts, and really look at the language that the management uses to talk about how they managed their own business. And so, and, you know, I don't -- I don't personally know the details of how the artificial intelligence did it, but it correlates certain words and the way they come together with performance.

MURPHY: So, how far down did you guys dig? Like, how low did you go? Because a company like Salesforces which is number one, they have a venture, we ran a venture capital funds.

O'KEEFE: Right.

MURPHY: So Salesforce is actively out there looking to acquire early-stage start-ups. Is there another 50 list of, kind of, the 50 (INAUDIBLE) that's going start-ups or early stage companies?

O'KEEFE: Maybe we will expand that out. But one thing the BCG did do, was look at the investments that company's making, compared to high performing DC funds to, sort of, get a sense of like how good their investments are. So, that's an interesting way.

BARTIROMO: You're hitting on something so important right now. I'm so glad you brought it up, Mike, because you're right, Salesforce has an arm that invests and acquires smaller companies. That's why a lot of these companies as Amazon, you know, other big technology --

KELLY: Intel.

BARTIROMO: Intel, you're seeing large tech right now, have venture capital arm and they are acquiring some of the smaller, no-names out there.

O'KEEFE: You know, we have a story on Salesforce that goes deeper into what they're doing. They bought 55 companies since 2006.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

O'KEEFE: And Marc Benioff, you know, a lot of times, like, maybe he doesn't even exactly know what they're going to do with the company but he knows there's an interesting technology and they make it an acquisition, they figure out how it's going to impact their business.

KELLY: Is there a super surprised company, for you, because I'm looking at this list and I'm not surprised by it, but I think people could be as the intercontinental exchange that, you know, they run the New York stock exchange, but really, those companies, the exchange have been focusing on data, licensing, it's not really --

BARTIROMO: A lot of (INAUDIBLE) mergers.

KELLY: Exactly. So, is there a company on this list that surprised you the most?

O'KEEFE: Surprised me the most, I mean, I'm a little surprised -- Monster Beverage is a really interesting company.

KELLY: Number 20 on that list.

O'KEEFE: Because they have been growing fast for 20 years, and, you know, I don't drink Monster Beverage drinks, but a lot of people do. They're really smart about how they market their brand, they don't really do a lot of advertising but they do a lot of really cool, sort of, sponsorship stuff. And they just, you know, they keep growing that company year after year.

KELLY: And the next leg of growth for Monster Beverage is over in China and Asia, so that's where they're looking to go so if you follow the stock close, you can see they've dominated North America and they've slowly been making inroads and smart positioning in Asia.

BARTIROMO: Look at that chart.

O'KEEFE: You know we have MasterCard and Visa on the list. And I think that's really interesting because they seemed like, you know, it's the card in your wallet. But they're really doing a lot of innovative things. They are trying to be, you know, the future of payments in all different forms.

MURPHY: And when we talk about big tech companies or fin-tech companies doing acquisitions, early-stage investing. But there's also companies like Campbell Soup has (INAUDIBLE) so it's not just big tech that's looking to acquire small innovative companies. I think it's across all diferent --

BARTIROMO: Campbell Soup, wow. And these guys are computer guys like you. We had Ann Winblad on from Winblad, who is a great venture capitalist. And she said, I'm competing with the arms of the soft, you know, of the SoftBanks, not SoftBanks, of the --

MURPHY: The large corporations.

BARTIROMO: The large corporation. The largest technology --

KELLY: Imagine if the repatriation happens, of the taxes of all those trillions of dollars overseas to these companies that they can then re- invest since small businesses start up, things that are happening. I mean, not to tie this into the whole tax reform overhaul policy but that could be a good next leg of growth for this company.

O'KEEFE: First, they have to find the right things to invest in.

KELLY: Yes, of course.

BARTIROMO: These lists are helpful. Brian, thank you so much, Brian O'Keefe joining us. We wanted to also -- should we take a look at IBM real quick. I mean, IBM was obviously stalled in terms of its revenue growth for 22 quarters. You saw a decline in revenue but yesterday, check out that stock yesterday. Nine percent, one of the reasons the Dow Industrials hit 23,000. I just wanted to mention that, is this a turning point for IBM?

MURPHY: I don't think so. I think when you see that type of move, so much of the volume in the markets right now is computer driven or algorithmic trading. That, to me, smells like a short covering -- short squeeze.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll keep watching IBM. Obviously, IBM, GE, two- story stocks that we want to look at today. Brian, good to see you, thank you. Coming up next, the fight is growing over Catalonia's push for independence. How the Spanish government is trying to stop the region's succession, that's next. And then a terrifying close call, more video of that scary fly by that put 200 passengers at risk. We'll tell you all about it, back in a moment, straight ahead.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back! Markets are down this morning after a huge day yesterday. Dow Industrials' expected to be down better than 100 points. No surprise. The market crossed 23,000 yesterday for the first time ever in a big rally, and, of course, we're up to better than $5 trillion in market value since the election.

A couple names on the move, Gilead Sciences; the stock right now is up almost three percent in the premarket after winning FDA approval for a new cancer gene therapy -- used to treat lymphoma. The pharmaceutical giant will sell the treatment at $373,000. It's only the second gene therapy to earn approval from the FDA on that. Novartis brought the first drug of this class to market back in August.

EBay shares this morning on the move after delivering third-quarter earnings after the bell last night. The results were roughly in line but fourth-quarter guidance's disappointed. EBay is revamping its online marketplace amid tough competition from Amazon. Stock, right now, taken a real hit down 6-1/2 percent in the premarket.

And then, there's Spain, the government there is set to activate an emergency measure to take control of Catalonia, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, Maria. So, Spain's government calling a special cabinet for the weekend to activate this measure -- it allows for the central government to take over the semiautonomous power of any of the country's17 regions. Now, this comes after Catalonia's leader said, Separatist lawmakers, can vote in favor of declaration of independence. The measure has never been used in the four decades since democracy was restored in Spain.

Well, an Air Berlin pilot is in big trouble. He performed a risky flying stunt with 200 passengers aboard. You're watching the video of it right now. Reports say he buzzed Dusseldorf Airport terminal in a maneuver that was met to mark the bankrupt last Trans-Atlantic flight. Well, a pilot of another told Reuters that a go-around should only be performed for its operations, or safety aviation officials are looking at this video and looking into this incident.

Well, Blue Apron, they are tightening their belt. The company has laid out six percent of the workforce, that's about 300 workers, as part of a company or organization. Blue Apron has struggled since it went public back in June with its stock price cut in half since then. Competition from a rival, a big one that would-be Amazon. There is the year to date chart, you can see it on your screen.

Meanwhile, Sea World is laying off 350 workers due to low attendance at its parks -- mainly in Orlando and San Diego. They've been trying to rebuild the brand solving protests over its treatment of their killer whales. Shares of Sea World, down more than 34 percent year to date.

And then, finally this, Snickers are getting a facelift, actually three facelifts. The candy company announcing they're going to release a line of three new flavors to combat a number of different, well, emotional issues. Feeling irritable, wimpy, indecisive? Well, they've got the cure. These three bars: espresso, fiery, and salty and sweet, Maria. Right now, I think I want the espresso. I'm a little tired.

BARTIROMO: Wow! Yes, the expresso sounds good.

KELLY: Thanks to wimpy for fiery, right? Like, I like spicy stuff, but it doesn't mean that I'm a wimp.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: He's taking it personally.

GABRIELLE: So -- but personally, I'm really concerned about the espresso one, because if you're irritable, I think the last thing you actually need is to have some more caffeine. More caffeine. I always like those names, though. I actually find that really attractive. When you're in a store and you're looking at candy and you're like, yes, you know, I kind of feel irritable.

BARTIROMO: But do you buy right there? Or will you buy it because of that?

GABRIELLE: No. Only if I really want it.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell, speaking out over the national anthem protest. What he said to players and how they're reacting, next. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Well, it's a big night at Wrigley Field last night. The Cubs fought for their playoff lives and they survived. Jared Max with the highlights, Jared.

urn:contentItem:5V9M-1391-F084-B135-00000-00'Market on tenterhooks' as investors await latest earnings from Big Tech2019-01-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:40ZLexisNexisPg. A12'Market on tenterhooks' as investors await latest earnings from Big Tech

Apple Inc. will kick off what may prove to be a crucial earnings week for the world's tech giants on Tuesday amid concerns that it may stumble out of the gate.

After a miserable December that saw the Nasdaq Composite Index and the S&;P500 enter bear market territory, North American markets have rebounded in January, easing fears that a global slowdown could lead into a recession. Since Dec. 31, the Nasdaq Composite Index is up 6.7 per cent, while the S&;P/TSX Composite Index gained more than seven per cent.

The market's bounceback hasn't comforted Horizons ETFs portfolio manager Hans Albrecht, who describes it as a "show-me-first market" - one that requires positive results to convince investors to buy in. With Apple, Amazon.com Inc. and Facebook Inc. each reporting this week, it's set to get its first major test of 2019.

"I think the market is on tenterhooks," said Albrecht, who runs a covered-call fund that is made up of some of the largest tech companies in the world. "I think at any moment we could see a resumption of that selling."

Of the tech giants, Albrecht and KeyBanc Capital Markets analyst Andy Hargreaves agree that Apple is the one investors should be most concerned with. In terms of its impact on the market, Apple's earnings could signal broader issues in the global market, Hargreaves said. In a letter to investors, Apple CEO Tim Cook already warned that revenue for the company's first fiscal quarter, which ended on Dec. 29, would be 15 per cent weaker than expected, blaming the shortfall on iPhone sales in China.

Although the company, which shocked analysts last year by announcing it would no longer publish iPhone sales numbers before posting an earnings miss, has already announced its bad news, analysts are still in the dark over guidance. Should those numbers fail to impress, it would suggest to Hargreaves that the company's issues have seeped into its other products and other geographical locations. Even though Apple's stock has plunged more than 33 per cent since hitting a peak in October, it remains a risky play.

"I'm still of the view that there's more risk there than opportunity for upside even with the big reset because the perception there is that it's still mostly a China issue ... and that the rest of the world is fine," Hargreaves said.

While poorly received guidance from Apple could offer yet another sign of a global slowdown and convince investors to sell, an earnings miss for Facebook would be treated differently, Hargreaves said. For the social media company, which has seen headline risk mainly over privacy concerns, a miss would instead be seen as a company-specific problem, lessening its potential to drag the market down.

According to BMO Capital Markets analyst Daniel Salmon, the stock is still expected to outperform as long as "Custom Audiences capabilities are not hindered by regulation and negative press doesn't thwart agencies/brands, but visibility remains low."

Due to the possible return of volatility, Albrecht suggested investors should dip into the options market for protection. Buying puts on the individual names would leave investors at the mercy of inflated volatility, he said. He suggests buying six-month to one-year put options on the Nasdaq Composite Index with a 12 per cent strike range on the downside, he said. They're more expensive than short-term puts, he said, but would protect investors in the event the FAANG stocks are responsible for volatility returning to the market.
